We have a situation where, certainly in the Western Australian context—the member for Perth would know of this—small businesses in our state involved particularly in mining and the resources sector are obliged to compete in the marketplace, offering their services against CSIRO and Ausmap, which do not pass on the true cost of their work to their clients and, as a consequence, are providing subsidised services to those consumers. They are skewing the market against the small business interests of those service providers—those consultants—who are obviously not subsidised and who are forced to pass on the true cost of their service to the clients.

The problem is that this work should and could be done by people in private enterprise. It is not just me who says this. The coalition's own national competition policy says this. Yet the coalition flouts its own policy and allows this to happen because these agencies are doing this in response to some of the budget cuts.

BREAK.PARA: Will the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs or the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) explain this to the electorate? I say this because part of the government's problem is that small business thinks it is being let down, and it is now losing faith in the coalition creed. I read today where the Yellow Pages small business index has reported a slump in support for the government's small business policies from 42 to 20 per cent. The percentage of those in the small business sector who think government policies are working against them has risen from six to 22 per cent. This is an indictment by the many people who believed that their future was better served by the coalition than Labor. Minister Prosser is like the emperor with new clothes, claiming that these figures do not mean anything and that two-thirds of business expects sales and profits to increase over the next 12 months.

I find this attitude astounding. The minister is claiming credit for the economic improvement of this country, more rightly down to the actions of other ministers in the coalition as some sort of compensation for the fact that promised improvements for small business have not occurred. You cannot escape the fact that small business people are disenchanted. It is because he has not given what he promised in the government's first 12 months.

We must not forget that small business is also probably the best way to reduce unemployment in this country. I note in the same article in the paper this morning that Parliamentary Library researchers now believe that the coalition holds more than half of the electorates in this country with high unemployment rates. Even as a matter of self‐preservation, I would have thought that the minister would have been prodded by all those backbenchers in marginal seats with high unemployment rates to lift his game to help small business. It begs this question: why have a minister for small business if it is not going to make an ounce of difference? It raises people's expectations unnecessarily. When they are dashed, they feel even more aggrieved towards the coalition government.

The minister has indirectly acknowledged the performance of his peers on the front bench. Perhaps it is now time that one of these good performers took over this crucial role in cultivating small business prosperity. I know that on the back bench of the coalition there is an enormous amount of talent. It is my view that on the back bench there are people who could do the job far better than the minister. It is time that the Prime Minister took hold of the reins of office and ensured that the best performers are on the front bench. That is an attitude I am sure many on the back bench would agree with. I know that members of the opposition would probably also agree.

TALK.START.PARA: —Particularly if you are still there.
—It is very kind of the member for Perth to say that, but I am interested in looking at this from the perspective of my constituents.

BREAK.PARA: One particular program I want to refer to in the context of the portfolio of another poor performer in the government, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone), is the NEIS, or new enterprise incentive scheme. Another way that I believe small business has been penalised by the effects of this budget is in the reduction of funds to the new enterprise incentive scheme.

I have long had an involvement with people in the NEIS and am compelled by this government's action to stand in this place and defend what is probably one of the most effective business and employment programs in the country. I did the same when the former minister, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), was trying to get rid of the enterprise incentive scheme several years ago during the term of the Labor government.

On 28 June 1996, Minister Vanstone announced that the budget for NEIS had been cut nationally by one‐third but that the regional economic group, RED, and a number of the Western Australian managing agents have actually been cut by up to 66 per cent. This has had a very significant effect on the local labour market. At the time, the minister said:

The new enterprise incentive scheme is one of the most successful programs. However, it is one of the most expensive. The number of potential NEIS places for 1997-98 is being considered now as the federal budget is prepared for May this year.
I am concerned that if the number of places made available for NEIS is not increased, it will lead to a net increase in unemployment.

The NEIS program is unique in that not only do the participants create their own job through the establishment of their own small business but also these businesses end up as employers as well. At the last count, eight new and additional jobs were created for every 10 NEIS businesses established. This saved the Commonwealth an estimated $65.8 million in unpaid unemployment benefits last year. The NEIS program is one of the most cost effective employment generation programs in this country. Each real and sustainable job created by NEIS costs around $2,500.

The minister clearly has not taken these figures into account when deciding to cut NEIS. Cuts to NEIS really mean a loss in jobs potentially created by small business. I will make this observation: these are jobs for young people. Once again, young people are being targeted by cuts that, in many instances, come from ministers who are endeavouring to do the opposite, which is create work or opportunities for young people. The cuts in this budget can be directly correlated to a loss of 4,500 jobs that would have been created this financial year.

I am also stunned by the fact that the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs has not championed this program to his coalition colleagues. But he is not in cabinet, so how could he. He has all responsibility and no power. That is a problem that the Western Australians face with the fact that we do not have a cabinet minister in the coalition from Western Australia, which, in my view, is an absolute disgrace. It means that Western Australian interests are under‐represented. It also means that all those others who are either parliamentary secretaries or ministers from Western Australia are obliged to follow the cabinet line without any input. So Western Australia's interests are diluted considerably.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they say so publicly.

—Of course they say so publicly. This is the sum total of the incompetence of the Western Australian Liberal Party in its relationship with the Prime Minister. All I can say is that WA is suffering as a consequence of that incompetence.

BREAK.PARA: In 1995-96, 10,000 people established new businesses as a result of taking part in the NEIS program after undergoing training with one of the 150 managing agencies throughout Australia. DEETYA's latest post‐program monitoring data indicates 84 per cent positive outcomes for NEIS participants 15 months after business commencement. I was walking through the main street of Joondalup the other day when I bumped into a chap, as we all do as members. I could not quite place the face or the environment in which I had seen him. This chap was standing next to equipment from his business. He said, `Do you remember me, Paul? You spoke to us when Labor was trying to scrap NEIS. They stopped, fortunately. Look at me now. I've been in business for four years. I'm employing people.' That was as a result of the then government and this government's most successful program. They now want to cut it. It is absolutely unbelievable.

Translated to the general small business sector, such positive outcomes would represent a community saving of hundreds of millions of dollars from unemployment benefits through prevention of bankruptcies alone. The NEIS program is not only cost effective; it generates a net return for the community through its effective business program. To continue to dismantle it in the knowledge of what has been done and what can be achieved represents social vandalism by the two ministers concerned.

In the time remaining, I want to touch on Austudy. It is a subject that is very sensitive to backbenchers in the government. It has been a serious problem because of the disastrous inability of many Australians to obtain Austudy support following changes in the management of the scheme by the government. Potentially thousands of people are unable to enrol in courses of study this year through lack of financial support. That is on top of the fact that they have seen the increase in the threshold age of independence from 22 to 25. It is slightly mind boggling for a government that is supposed to represent self-determination and self-starting to claim that people are not independent up to the age of 25. It is very hard to understand. I find explaining that to the families who come to me in my constituency office very difficult, particularly as many of them are in what I consider to be the core constituency of the coalition—that is, families raising children.

In defence of the government, however, I believe that there was sufficient evidence that people were obtaining Austudy support where they should not have been entitled to it. This has been especially prevalent among families where trusts were used to limit assessable income. The government was right to act to remedy this. Unfortunately, the problem is in the way that it has been done. In order to restrict one group, a much larger group of genuinely deserving people has been prevented from gaining access to Austudy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sledgehammer approach.
—I have seen that happen from your side of politics. In this instance, I would have expected better.

BREAK.PARA: I could go on for some time over these subjects. I wish to conclude by saying this. The Prime Minister has an extraordinary range of talent on the back benches in his party. It is time for him to reshuffle his ministry to bring forward this new talent so that we can avoid the unfortunate and incompetent actions of some of the ministers in this government which have resulted in the small business community, for instance, having such a poor view of the government's performance. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments today about trade and industry policy. As we are dealing with Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1996‐97 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1996‐97, one is able to make some wide‐ranging remarks in respect of general matters. There are a couple of matters contained within the bills themselves which relate to trade and industry matters that I will draw particular attention to and make some general comments about following upon that.

SPEECH.PARA: The second reading speech on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) was given by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Jull), who most recently has started taking an interest in the car industry for various reasons. In the minister's second reading speech, he referred to a $30 million package of alternative assistance to Howe Leather following the agreement reached with the United States to remove automotive leather from eligibility under the TCF import credit scheme and the PMV export facilitation scheme. That is recorded on page 26 of the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) under the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism. Under `Other Services' at division 917 of that department's appropriations, an amount of $30 million is recorded.

The dispute over Howe Leather was, in my view, a direct result of the government's misplaced notion of aggressive bilateralism, which was the hallmark of the coalition election commitments of the Minister for Trade (Mr Fischer). Shortly after the coalition won office a year ago, the United States ambassador to Australia, Mr Perkins, made the point that the notion of aggressive bilateralism means that if you punch a trading partner, they tend to punch back. The empty threats of the Minister for Trade saw the United States punch back over Howe Leather. As a consequence, we saw, in conjunction with the World Trade Organisation meeting in Singapore in December last year, an alleged agreement between the government on behalf of Australia and the United States administration whereby Howe Leather was provided with an alternative package of $30 million.

I describe it as alleged, because I notice the other day when the then acting US trade representative, Charlene Barshefsky, was before the US Senate finance committee at her confirmation hearing, in the written answers she supplied to questions before the committee she made the point—which was reported in the Australian Financial Review in recent days—that the Australian government, from the United States administration's eyes, seemed to have replaced one unfair and WTO inconsistent regime with another. This is a very far-flung point from the assertion of an agreement in respect of Howe Leather. Those employees at Howe Leather who may have seen that reference from the now trade representative Barshefsky can be legitimately entitled to wonder about the implications for their jobs and future if what was trumpeted loudly by the government, the Minister for Trade and the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) as a done deal with the United States is now a done deal which is apparently at risk. We await with interest any further developments as far as the Howe Leather compensation package is concerned.

The second particular area that I want to refer to arising out of the bills themselves is found in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) at page 53. Again, it is to do with the Department of Industry, Science and Tourism where reference is made to changed appropriations so far as bounty and subsidy assistance is concerned.

The relevant acts that that particular appropriation refers to are the Bounty (Books) Act, the Bounty (Machine Tools and Robots) Act and the Bounty (Ships) Act. This is a reference to the decision by the government in last year's budget to effectively terminate a range of bounties—the shipbuilding bounty, the computer bounty and the book bounty—and its decision, again towards the end of last year, to make some changes in the timing of the termination of those arrangements.

The one which is of particular interest to me is the shipbuilding bounty, and that arises largely as a consequence of Australia's shipbuilding industry being now exclusively an export industry and Australia's shipbuilding industry being now found almost exclusively in sheds in Henderson, south of Fremantle, and in Tasmania. None of our Tasmanian colleagues are here, so I will not raise the question as to which state performs better.

The key point to make is that at a point in the cycle where Australia's shipbuilding industry had turned itself exclusively into an export industry in fierce competition with European nations, particularly northern Europe—building new fast ferries, aluminium fast ferries and catamarans—and at precisely the point in the cycle where some European nations increased their subsidies, the government took the step of abolishing the shipbuilding bounty. The subsidies which are given to our competitors in northern Europe far outweigh the original subsidies provided by the shipbuilding bounty in any event. Those decisions, in particular in respect of the shipbuilding bounty, reflect a more general approach to trade, industry and export enhancement policy which the government has adopted since it came to office.

To conclude on the shipbuilding bounty, I noticed in the last couple of weeks that the chairman of the Australian Shipbuilding Association, who is also the managing director of Austel Ships in Henderson in Western Australia, issued a press release making the point that, as a direct consequence of the government's decision in this area, they had not been able to win any further contracts in the shipbuilding area and they were proposing to put 300 of their workers on notice that they would lose their jobs as a direct consequence of the government's changed arrangements so far as the shipbuilding bounty is concerned.

You could not get a better example of the government's trade, industry and export policy taking the nation in precisely the wrong direction. In the end, trade and industry are about economic growth and about jobs and we need to do everything we can to enhance economic growth and to enhance jobs. With the prospect of 300 workers losing their jobs in Henderson in Fremantle, there is no better illustration of the wrong direction in which the government is taking us so far as trade and industry enhancement policy is concerned.

There are a number of clear points of contrast between the government and the opposition in this area. The first point of contrast is in the trade and export enhancement area. In express breach of election commitments, we saw in the last budget the government make its decision either to abolish or massively gut a range of export enhancement programs.

In express breach of an election commitment, the government cut Austrade appropriations by $90 million per year and cut EMDG appropriations by $426 million over four years. That was an express breach of an election promise which had the effect that the maximum cut of appropriations from Austrade and EMDG combined would be $58.6 million. There was an express breach of a personnel commitment that the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister gave to the book publishers association that there would be no tinkering in any substantial way with the export market development grants scheme.

So in the area of export facilitation, in the main program to help small and medium sized exporters to enhance their export activity, we have seen a massive slashing of funds allocated to the EMDG scheme and a cap of $150 million placed on that scheme by the government. That $150 million cap includes the cost of administration, which is calculated by the department to be in the order of up to $7.5 million. So the maximum amount that the government is prepared to allocate to assist small and medium sized companies for export enhancement under that scheme is effectively going to be $142.5 million per year.

This is despite the government's own documentation in the budget papers showing that, for every dollar spent under the EMDG scheme, there is an export ratio return of anywhere between eight to one and 24 or 25 to one, depending upon whether the exporter is a new exporter or an exporter that has been exporting for a number of years. So there is a massive export ratio benefit and the government cuts off Australia's nose to spite its face by simply looking at a penny pinching, rationalist bottom line.

That approach, that method, is being reflected in a range of other areas in industry enhancement—gutting $2 billion out of research and development and cutting the support by way of industry bounties or subsidies, which I have referred to. The whole thematic policy approach of the government in its industry, trade and export enhancement policies to date has been to remove or massively reduce the incentives and programs that assist Australian exporters and Australian companies in this area.

The second point of contrast in the government's approach to trade, industry and export enhancement and the approach of those on this side of the House is found in the government's trade outcomes and objectives statement, which the Minister for Trade and Deputy Prime Minister tabled in the House on 5 February. There are a number of points that are worth making about that particular statement.

Firstly, the statement contains no reference or mention of any jobs target or any employment target, and this stands in stark contrast to the last trade outcomes and outlooks statement of the previous government, when the then senator, now member for Canberra, Bob McMullan, was Minister for Trade. Labor's last trade outlook statement contained an express commitment to reduce unemployment to five per cent by the year 2000. We find lots of mantra chanting about jobs in Mr Fischer's document but no objectives in real terms, no jobs or unemployment targets.

The second thing that we find in Mr Fischer's statement, despite the fact that we find all this mantra chanting about jobs, is weasel words about exports making a contribution to growth in the economy. But when we look at the government's budget papers—firstly, the budget papers of last year and, secondly, the mid-year review released by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in the course of this year—we find the government's own budget papers forecast that exports will make a negative contribution to growth in GDP in the 1996-97 financial year and the 1997-98 financial year. That is a drop from a plus one per cent contribution to growth in GDP by net exports in the course of 1995-96.

So under the approach of those on this side of the House, enhancing trade, enhancing economic growth, enhancing the array of incentives to Australian companies to export, we find in 1995-96—our effective last full year in office—a one per cent contribution and the government's own forecasts are a negative contribution for 1996-97 and 1997-98. At precisely that point in the cycle, we find this massive gutting of export and trade enhancement programs.

The next key point we find in the minister's statement is an almost obsessive focus on the notion of bilateralism. This was the hallmark of the coalition's trade policy in the run-up to the last election. Whilst there are some concessions made to regionalism and to multilateralism, the focus is essentially on bilateral arrangements. In an era of multilateral trade obligations, it is clear that you need to be able to push bilateral arrangements, regional arrangements and multilateral arrangements but not focus exclusively and solely on bilateral arrangements.

Arising out of that, in the course of the statement tabled by the Minister for Trade, we find about 10 countries listed in his statement as the key markets for the next two years. There is a consistent thread which flows through the key sectoral markets and the key sectoral industries, which the minister's statement draws attention to as priorities. We not only find a focus on bilateralism but also a focus on agricultural and mineral raw commodities exports. This is despite the outlook statement's own analysis that the great shift in international trade over the last 15 years and into the future is into manufactures, services and value added exports.

So on the one hand we find the government's own statement talking about growth and jobs coming from trade and export. We find the government's own budget papers and mid-year review talking about, under their policies, that being a net negative contribution to growth. We find the government's own analysis in the trade document referring to the shift in international trade into manufactures, value addeds and services—and that is matched with the government's sectoral priorities being in the minerals and agricultural raw commodities.

While it is the case that our traditional commodities remain of vital importance to Australia, we have to follow that shift in international trade. We follow that shift in international trade by doing what we can to maximise our effort so far as small and medium sized companies are concerned in the value adding, in the manufactures and in the services areas.

Recently, I had the opportunity to go to Ballarat. In the course of my time in Ballarat, I spent time with a quite differing array of exporting companies. One was a company exporting computer software services, another was a group of potato growers trying to get into value added activity and exporting to Japan and another was a group of automotive exporters to the United States. All of these exporters in Ballarat reflect the diversity and the mix of Australia's export basket. All in their own way emphasise the need to be putting our policy focus on value adding, on manufactures, on services and on products to follow that shift in international trade.

The other disappointing feature in the trade outlook statement is that we find no notion of aggressive multilateralism contained in the government's policy. In the course of Ambassador Barshefsky's appearance before the Senate finance committee at her confirmation, she enhanced what she had previously articulated as a United States strategic enforcement strategy so far as World Trade Organisation obligations are concerned. Before the Senate committee at the end of January, Ambassador Barshefsky had this to say:

Our willingness to enforce trade laws and existing agreements is crucial to our support at home and our credibility abroad. The Administration has brought a record number of enforcement actions by using all the trade tools at our disposal—48 actions in the past year. And we have reinvigorated efforts to ensure compliance with all of our trade agreements whether negotiated by us or previous administrations. We have aggressively fought against the market closing practises of competitors using the leverage provided in Section 301—
that is, section 301 of their trade act—
to open foreign markets and ensure fair treatment for our goods and services.

We have filed 21 cases to enforce U.S. rights under the new dispute settlements procedures of the World Trade Organization—having filed 15 complaints in the last year alone. This caseload is absolutely unprecedented in the history of the GATT and WTO, and we have already begun to see the benefits our enforcement efforts have yielded for U.S. firms and workers. Of the 21 cases brought by us, we reached settlements in six cases and we have prevailed in two cases so far that were referred to panel. The real successes are the settlements that we reach . . .
She goes on to say:

The new WTO dispute settlement rules often make it possible for us to enforce WTO agreements without ever having to reach a panel decision. The fact that the WTO can and will authorize us to retaliate enables us to reach earlier settlements, opening markets for more of our exports.

This is precisely the mechanism used against us by the United States in the Howe Leather case, and the Minister for Trade announced earlier this year that we were pursuing a similar mechanism against Hungary in respect of some of Hungary's agricultural subsidies. The great disappointment in the trade outlook statement is that our action against Hungary is not the tip of the iceberg, but it is the iceberg itself.

If you want to maximise Australia's opportunity for exports, and in an era of multilateral trade liberalisation, you have to do two things: you have to run an aggressive industry development policy to ensure that your export mix can follow the shift of international trade, but you also need to run an aggressive multilateral trade policy. That means you have to use the enforcement mechanisms of the WTO to ensure that our trading partners are up to the mark so far as WTO obligations are concerned and to ensure that the world is not tilted against us. The great disappointment, so far as multilateral obligations are concerned in the minister's document is that it is clear that we are not following the model of the Barshefsky's strategic enforcement strategy to maximise our WTO obligations and to maximise the benefit which will come from trade to Australian jobs and to Australian workers. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak in this appropriation debate dealing with appropriation bills Nos 3 and 4. Given the tradition of having a wide ranging debate, I will range widely over a number of government departments. At the outset, looking at the appropriation for the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, let me express my disappointment as I have expressed before with the cut through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to international organisations dealing with family planning programs. There was a lot of lobbying about this. I felt that the cut to the United Nations program was nothing short of an absolute disaster and, as usual under this government, has sent all the wrong messages about Australia's standing.

SPEECH.PARA: In overall terms the amount of money we were giving was not huge but it was very important to those programs, especially programs in our part of the world. When I was in Samoa earlier this year, people were asking what was likely to be in the budget and whether their family planning programs were likely to be cut. I said I could not give any guarantees. I was no longer a member of the government party. I was a member of the opposition. I did not have access to any knowledge. But even I did not realise the savageness of the cuts that would be imposed.

I do not want to say that religion played a part in this but, like everyone else, no way would I agree to some of the arguments that have been pushed about coercion and forced family planning. But you just have to go to those countries of the South Pacific or in our parts of the world and see the very necessary programs that are there. I will continue to say it is a great pity that they were cut. I do hope that the funding to those programs dealing with family planning can be restored at the first opportunity.

Only last week I had a group of young people come to see me complaining that they had been ripped off over a music training scheme—one of these programs that, under the former government, allowed these young people to be given training in the music industry. I was very careful to find out that the Commonwealth had met all its responsibilities. These people had got their training; they had got their payment; and at the end of their training they were picked up by a private enterprise. It is always being paraded how wonderful private enterprise is. However, it was when private enterprise stepped in employing the young people that the sorry saga commenced.

These young people had not received their proper pay or working conditions. I had a look at the contract that they had signed; that was not being met. Being one of those dreadful people that the government points to as a trade unionist, of which I am very proud, my first question to these young people was: `Have you discussed this with your union? You are obviously being ripped off. You're not being paid the correct amount of money. They're not abiding by the conditions that you were employed under.'

These young people—and this is coming from the centre of trade unionism, the Illawarra—looked at me in some amazement and they pointed out to me, rightly, that this was their very first job and that they were not in a union. In fact, I got the impression that they did not know very much about unions. I explained to them the role of the union, how important it was and how the union could step in.

I contacted the union myself and, although these young people were not members of the union, the union agreed to become involved in the case to see what they could do to get these young people their proper entitlements—which is now happening. This for me is not an isolated case. Time and time again people come to see me about ripped off. I know they come to see all members of parliament when they are being ripped off.

Recently I had a boat builder, who had been employed for some 18 months, come to see me because at no time had he been paid the correct wage. I come from an area of very high unemployment. It is easy for people like me who are in a well paid job to say, `Why did you accept that?' But I have not got a big mortgage; I do not have a couple of kids that I have to feed. These people are frightened of losing their jobs. We say, `They should not take this; they should know better.' It is easy from our position to pass judgment. As I say, this person had been employed by a boat builder for some 18 months and had at no time been paid the proper wage.

I have had another case of a firm in Wollongong called Death by Chocolate—a wonderful name—who had ripped off the young people working there when their establishments closed. Another example is U.F.I. Pools. The bosses were supposed to be paying the employees' contributions into a super fund but they were not. When the firm closed these people were left high and dry. The young people—be it the boat builder or those working for this firm called Death by Chocolate—are receiving no entitlements such as annual leave and superannuation.

The point I am making is that people do not realise the importance of unions until they run into problems. We hear from those on the other side ad nauseam about the freedom to join a union, freedom of choice, the right to be in a union or not in a union. I have never in my life seen a non-union member, who is so proud of being a non-union member, refuse to take the pay increase or refuse to accept the better working conditions fought for and gained by unions.

This is the basic hypocrisy of it: if these people who feel so strongly about the right not to be in a union, then for consistency's sake they should not take the benefits gained by the unions. They should not take the pay increase that the union gets. They should not take the better conditions that the union obtains for them, because they do not want to be in a union and they are exercising their democratic right not to be in a union.

We are told by this government that we are moving into a period of free enterprise. This is really great if you have the power and ability to negotiate your wages and conditions, but what about the young or those without a bargaining base; what about their conditions? It is great if you come from an industry where there is a demand for your skills. Of course you are going to get a good deal. But the idea of bargaining assumes that there is a degree of equality, that they are equals who are bargaining. But how can there be equality when, say, a 16- or 18-year-old school leaver is bargaining their pay and conditions for their first job with a management team or someone who has had a lot of experience in bargaining?

It is the trade union movement that has gained the proper wages and conditions for workers throughout this century. Those opposite make much of the decline in union membership but, like so many things, people never realise what they have until they need it. Time and time again people come to my office complaining about lack of conditions, about being exploited over their wages. These are always non-union members.

In my 14 years in this parliament, I cannot recall a union member coming to me with any of these complaints—not once. Every so often those opposite trot out the union membership of those on this side of the chamber. In an adjournment debate one day, I heard one of the members of the government stand up and list all the trade union affiliations of the members on our side.

Let me say that I am proud to be a trade unionist. I still retain my union membership and, in my own way, play an active part in the union. I would continue to press very strongly the importance of unionism and the benefits of the union. So often people do not realise the real benefits of a union until they come to need that benefit. That is when they realise the importance of it.

People assume that the bosses are always the well-meaning, benevolent, caring individuals that they like to portray themselves as. In the vast majority of cases—I dare not say that they are rogues—they are out to get the very best. If that means exploiting the worker and the conditions, they will still do it. It is no different in 1997 from what it was in 1897. They would still screw the workers into the ground if they could, and it is only the union that stops them doing it.

On another issue, but one that is equally important to me, people sometimes wonder and indeed ask us how much power an individual has. What is the point of attending a rally, writing a letter to a paper or indeed coming to see the MP when it seems that the omnipotent power of government and bureaucracy overrules all protests. I should like to outline to the chamber an example of where people power has had a tremendous victory in my own area. It shows that the might of the ordinary people, when they are united, can overcome obstinacy and bureaucracy.

This example involves Vodafone—one of these mobile phone groups that many people have heard about—who had decided, without consultation with anyone, to erect a 30-metre telecommunications tower at Dapto Showground which, I might say, is the gem of my electorate. What they had overlooked or ignored was the fact that it was to be erected within 300 metres of a primary school and also a child-care centre. When the local residents became aware of this, naturally they were outraged. They formed themselves into a committee, held public meetings and demanded answers from Vodafone—all of which they could not get. They involved both the local state member, the member for Illawarra, Terry Rumble, and me in the issue. We both wrote numerous letters to Vodafone which they refused to answer.

Finally, after a number of telephone calls just before Christmas, I eventually contacted someone at Vodafone and I was given to understand that work was to commence within days at the showground site. When we communicated this information to the locals, without hesitation the local residents rallied. On the morning that work was to commence, a crowd was at the gates of Dapto Showground from 6 a.m.—which is also the Dapto greyhound racing club; so we also had a lot of greyhound owners coming in there with their dogs.

The people there at that meeting resolved, with the support of the South Coast Labour Council and the local politicians, that a picket line would be maintained. The picket line was set up and was maintained over Christmas. Indeed, each of us was rostered there to work over Christmas Day. As it was, it was only when Vodafone agreed to a meeting with the residents and gave a written guarantee that no work would commence until after this meeting, that the picket line was somewhat downgraded. It was not necessary for me and a couple of others to spend our Christmas day on the picket line, although we had intended to do so.

But throughout this whole period, right up until a week ago, the locals had been maintaining a presence at Dapto Showground. So determined were the local people that they were prepared to picket over Christmas. For many of the people there, this was their first active protest. It was the first time many of them had ever been on a picket line and, naturally, a lot of people were quite concerned and apprehensive about what would happen. But they so believed in what they were doing that they were determined to overcome their apprehension and go on that picket line.

A meeting took place in my office with Vodafone on 17 February this year, and Vodafone agreed to consider alternative sites. The fact we told them that no way were we going to have the tower there and that, if necessary, we would see that no dog meeting took place there while ever they were proposing to put that tower up might have hastened their decision. They said that, while not categorically ruling out Dapto Showground, alternative sites would be investigated and no work would commence until they had reported back, which I hope will be next week.

What we are seeing here is an illustration that, when people believe passionately about an issue and are prepared to be united, they can achieve many things. It is always difficult when you single out people for mention because you inevitably miss many people, although I must say I have never seen the people of Dapto so united on any issue as they were on this issue. It is the strongest community feeling I have received on any issue in all the 14 years I have represented Dapto; it is the one issue that really united the people. Special mention should go to Yoke Berry, Barney Fittler, Tom Fitzgibbon, Noreen Hay and Neil Hicking who all took a leadership role in this picket line.

I would also like to take this opportunity to outline my concern about plans by the government to provide an additional period for telephone companies to be exempt from local and state planning laws. As you know, these companies—these cowboys with the mobile phones—are exempt from local government planning laws. At the moment, the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) is planning to allow the telephone companies an additional two months past the 1 July deadline this year to be exempt from the planning power. I think this is something we should resist wholeheartedly.

At that meeting in my office, Wollongong City Council came along with a map on which they had outlined various alternative sites. I must say that the Vodafone people, to give them their credit—although they should have done it six months earlier—did listen to the complaints of the people and did agree to look at alternative sites. They were quite surprised when Wollongong City Council produced this map. Wollongong City Council had a coloured map of the whole area, and on that they had identified alternative sites. On that map, the Vodafone people outlined the difficulties with the line which has to be there with no blockages.

This is becoming an increasing problem for local government areas because these mobile phone people just go willy-nilly all over the place. They are sticking towers up; they are not coordinating with each other; and they are just putting them up often in the most sensitive areas. I guess most of us here have got a mobile phone. I read in a newspaper yesterday that, after Finland, Australia is the second largest mobile phone user in the world. This is all in the space of 10 years. So, in many respects, we ourselves are part of the problem because we all insist on having these mobile phones.

BREAK.PARA: It is going to be an increasing problem for local government areas. The local governments do not have the power to impose restrictions—as they do in every other area—on these mobile phone people. It is very important that they get their acts together. I think many councils could take a lead from Wollongong City Council which has gone to the trouble of identifying these various areas.

In the couple of minutes that is left to me, I want to turn to another issue dealing with these appropriations. At the six elections that I have had the honour to fight and win—with an increased majority, I would like my colleagues to know, and the same will be with the seventh—the local small business associations always come out and campaign vigorously against me. They were always telling me how good the then opposition, now the government, would be. It is interesting to read an article in today's Sydney Morning Herald headed `Howard's honeymoon is over':
Small business has grown disenchanted with the Howard Government, with 80 per cent saying policies were either working against them or had not helped at all.
For the first time since the March 1996 election, more small businesses believed they are worse off under the new Government.

How true! The truth will out. Let us remember that we were the government who had an inquiry into small business and had plans for small business, but in masses they voted against us. So many people wanted to punish us, wanted their moment of glory—their 30 seconds of glory—and voted against us. Small business people have punished themselves for the next three years. There we are from the Sydney Morning Herald today.

Finally, in the 41 seconds left to me, let me support the member for Moore (Mr Filing) in his comments about Austudy and the disaster that this has caused. It was difficult enough under us. Austudy was never easy. There has been some abuse of it and it should be cleaned up. No-one supports abuse. But this government has taken a sledgehammer to Austudy and has disadvantaged so many people. I have had telephone call after telephone call from people who have not been able to get into the University of Wollongong and other universities. What this govt has done regarding Austudy has been an absolute disaster. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hatton, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —These appropriation bills Nos. 3 and 4 are the coalition's shadowlands—that dark grey, muted, sombre area of subdued and hazy light where it is difficult to distinguish between truth and falsity, between image and reality, between what is substantial and what is evanescent. These appropriation bills are the hidy holes, where the coalition had attempted to bury the administrative errors and mistakes they made in the August budget papers.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Deputy Speaker, a debate has two sides—or at least I thought so until I heard the debate on these appropriation bills. Where is the other side in this debate? Apart from the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, who introduced these bills, there are, to my reckoning, no coalition speakers. The government members, all bright‐eyed and bushy‐tailed little bunnies that they were, lined up last year to speak on the budget, but in this debate they are conspicuous by their absence—their total lack of enthusiasm to debate us on these bills. Where are they now? They have deserted the field. They have gone into hiding; they have gone to ground in their burrows. Why? Are they under instruction from the government whip not to speak, are they still shell‐shocked by community reaction to the coalition's budget's measures, or do they think that these appropriation bills are an outbreak of calicivirus?

BREAK.PARA: Well, Madam Deputy Speaker, we've got the ferrets out! We are going to whack them down those holes, work them down to those cosy little burrows and drive those cowering little coalition bunnies out of their burrows, out of the shadowlands and into the sharp glare of the sunlight.

While speaking on the budget, coalition members condemned us for the budget black hole. They praised their leaders for the great advances made in controlling government expenditure and gazed reverently on the budget papers as if they were tomes of great importance and substantial import. They utterly and absolutely endorsed without condition everything in those August budget papers. Members on the other side said that the changes such as those made to the Austudy means test would ensure that the system would not be rorted as they claimed it had been under the Labor government. Now they are silent on those changes. If they do speak about it, it is within their party room to complain bitterly about the effects on their constituents, who gave them a great whack over the ears during the Christmas break.

Welcome to government! Welcome to having to answer for the things that were done in the budget papers. Those constituents—those who voted so handsomely for the coalition on 2 March—have been slowly becoming aware of the pettiness and meanness of this government, and are realising that the swingeing ideologically‐driven cuts in the August budget really do hurt real people, who are now having a good hard think about this lot opposite.

Now we are in a position to see a little more of the confusion, the deceit or the simple lack of knowledge that was evident in the budget papers delivered by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in August. In those papers he made large cuts across many portfolios without due and careful thought or reason; he cut useful and beneficial programs. They were penny‐pinching measures by a government that has an ideological obsession with cutting without due thought or reason. I stated then, in my response to the budget, that I believed that the Treasurer, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and a number of other ministers really did not know what they were cutting when they were cutting into those programs. I said that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) did not know what the effects were going to be in her portfolio because, when pressed to answer questions in the House, she was utterly unable to provide any coherent arguments or answers—she just did not know. The Prime Minister has a recollection problem. The Minister for Family Services, so it seems, has a collection problem.

In the budget, the Department of Health and Family Services received an overall increase in allocation. That did not mean that all the programs were given increases. Some programs were cut quite harshly in that budget. An example of this is the program for assistance for people with disabilities. It received a cut, as did the housing and crisis accommodation program. These are programs that are not high profile; nor are they subject to the type of intense scrutiny that has often been given to other programs. They are programs that provide assistance to people with disabilities and those in dire need due to extreme personal circumstances.

Now we see that in these appropriation bills these two programs are receiving extra funds of the order of $17 million after $20 million was cut. So the government has saved $3 million for the time being and brought disruption to the lives of those in the community who can least afford it.

In Appropriation Bill(No. 4) I find that, for assistance for people with disabilities, the 1995‐96 program provided in the order of $59 million. That was cut in the Treasurer's 1996‐97 budget to $52 million. Yet in these bills there is $1.25 million for transition payments to the states over the Commonwealth‐State Disability Agreement. One would think that in the preparation of the budget the department and the minister could have made allocation for those transfer payments. Surely that is not something that has come out of the wind, or come up quickly without being able to be predicted fully. Therefore I think it should have been incorporated in the budget papers in the first instance.

Similarly, there is a sum of more than $8 million for paying transfers to the states under the Commonwealth‐State Disability Agreement. That $8 million brings the level of funding up even further than in the budget papers last year.

In the housing and crisis accommodation area, the supported accommodation assistance program has been increased by $12 million. The argument put forward in the short notes presented by the Minister for Administrative Services argued that there was more work being done more quickly in this program. Surely the distance between last August and now is not so great that that could not have been predicted and incorporated into the original budget program.

Overall, in the budget papers last year, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) attempted to show an awful underlying structural deficit instead of using the headline deficit that we would normally use through most years. He used that as an argument to undertake cuts that he claimed were necessary and entirely in line with coalition philosophy. The great argument he put was based on the substantial notion that they knew the public at large would not wear the kind of cuts they were going to get without a substantial reason. He put up what he thought was a substantial reason, bodgie though it was.

This government claims that there was a huge deficit that needed urgent attention. The reality is that they switched the headline and the underlying structural deficit and they switched Labor programs for $7 billion worth of coalition programs. But, in their ERC, they cut and hacked and slashed and burnt in an attempt to drive everything down so that they could have the kind of government they dream of and the kind of government they think is a model for efficiency and openness. This has meant that many people have been forced to suffer entirely unnecessarily in the process. That includes not only individual people and those who could least afford to suffer; major programs were cut on an ideological basis.

One of those programs related to the bounty legislation, or the books, boats and bits part of the budget. The government saw the bounty legislation as a typical waste of government money under Labor. They said that it was a waste whilst Labor was in government and that they were not going to continue the program. Unfortunately for them, the business sector did not entirely hold the same views. Industry and business, particularly those who were affected, saw these programs as a way to promote export business and to assist businesses to break into a difficult export area. These programs gave small and medium businesses the opportunity and incentives to compete overseas. It also showed the world that the Australian government had a serious and export oriented industry policy.

There are companies in this country that have made advances into difficult markets, often in very difficult situations with opposition firms circling like vultures over contracts. With so much against them and with very limited resources available, the bounties provided by the Labor government were the incentive needed by many to make the leap into exporting. More importantly for this country, it enabled them to win those contracts and gain valuable earnings.

Because of the Labor Party's strong and insistent argument in the House of Representatives and the Senate, the government has had to backtrack on the bounty legislation. We think they have not gone far enough. They have not supported the book industry, the boat industry or the robotics industry sufficiently. Those industries demonstrated that, with the bounties, they could do good business here and particularly do good business in exporting. They have had to backtrack.

A multitude of Labor initiatives have been discarded by this government. The coalition have claimed that many of them were directed at special interest groups and were not needed by the vast majority of the population, especially the conservative heartland.

There is one policy born from the Labor Party that you would think would not come under that rationale. The policy that has been completely discarded is regional development. We know the actuality; every time that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) gets up to answer a question in the House, there is a catcall from the opposition saying, `No. Just transport.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, very rude.

—That is utterly true and apt. Why? Because, with the responsibilities he has in the regional development area, the budget in 1996-97 cut the funding for regional development. He was left with about $5 million to assist with the running of what, we do not know. Maybe it is running the office. It could let those people involved have something to do and to take their time with it.

BREAK.PARA: However, this program of regional development was created by the former Labor government in the One Nation and Working Nation programs. Regional development became a way for areas of the country isolated from the mainstream of development to utilise their assets and promote themselves. It gave regions a focus and the support they needed to build some sort of framework to develop and grow.

The outcome of that government budget cut last year can be readily seen at the federal level when the federal minister responsible met with the states to speak about regional development. There is an enlightening article by David Humphries in the Sydney Morning Herald of 25 February, from which I wish to quote. He says:

Little wonder, then, that regional development, the old political backburner, is beginning to generate a little heat. The problem for its advocates is that it's mostly disappearing out the spout of political expediency and gobbledegook.
He continues:

Take a high farce acted out in Canberra on February 7 at the aptly titled "Commonwealth‐State‐Territory ministerial meeting on regional development". I say aptly titled because about all the ministers did was meet.

Hendy Cowan, the Western Australian Deputy Premier who plays politics in the bullocking manner he once employed as a handy bush footballer, was so unimpressed he questioned whether it was sensible spending taxpayer dollars resuming such meetings if they were to be just "exchanges of information".

NSW's Michael Egan questioned the prudence of issuing a post-meeting communique, given that it would reveal the ministers had achieved nothing and attended for no good reason. The communique went ahead, mouthing platitudes about the need for greater co-operation.
He finishes with this:

The argument used to be about how money for regional development was spent. Now it's about whether there is any to spend. The Federal Parliamentary Secretary for Regional Development, Michael Ronaldson, had a simple answer. "Everything is gone," he told the meeting.

Ronaldson was referring to the $150 million cut from the Federal Government's regional development budget last year, leaving a jokingly paltry $5 million a year for just the next two years. This helps employ what is left of the Federal Department of Regional Development, a rump of six staff.

Federal spending on regional development is now less than a dollar a person a year in regional Australia. And this from a Federal Government swept to power on a swing registered most profoundly in the bush. The Feds' explanation is they have no constitutional role in regional development.

He goes on to argue that, despite that and what they have said to the states and despite the fact that there was an entirely farcical meeting between the responsible state ministers and the federal minister—and they really were there about nothing because there was simply no funding—a couple of ministers in the government, such as the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson) and Senator Hill, the Minister for the Environment, have a slush fund that they work up and which they are responsible for. There is no oversight of it. They do not have to give any credit to anyone in the parliament as to how those funds are spent. It is somewhat anomalous that, while they have cut the federal Department of Transport and Regional Development, effectively the slush funds for regional development have been handed to two coalition ministers to spend as they wish.

In August, the Treasurer said that he was going to make the government more efficient and streamline government programs. Of course, his primer of economic efficiency was something he initiated himself, the National Commission of Audit. I have labelled that document Fightback mark III. It is Fightback without the GST, at least not yet. In that August budget, inefficient and wasteful programs were to be either eliminated or reduced in their allocation.

In these bills and in recent events, we see what has really happened behind those cuts. In Fightback, the argument was that if there was any cross between the federal government and the states, in any area where there was an overlap the federal government should get out of the game and hand those responsibilities back to the states. In handing them back to the states, they should give them those programs at a 10 per cent discount because there would not be as much administrative work to do. That is pretty mean and spiteful and pretty much in line with what they have done to the Australian people at large. The great federalists have given the states some of their new corner.

It is interesting that in the legal aid area the states have responded to the coalition bringing in their philosophy full bore. The federal Attorney-General (Mr Williams) yesterday, according to a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Jodie Brough, ruled out increasing legal aid funding after a state counterpart ridiculed a desperate attempt to persuade the states to contract their services to the Commonwealth. The article states:
The plan was revealed in an extraordinary leaked letter by the West Australian Attorney-General, Mr Peter Foss—
a coalition person—
who labelled Budget cuts to legal aid of $120 million as "reprehensible" and Mr Williams's peace proposal as "quite offensive".
They are harsh words from one coalition state minister to a federal minister. The article continues:

Mr Williams's proposal followed States' threats to walk out of the national legal aid network and set up their own services for cases under State law, in response to Mr Williams's decision not to fund State cases.

The core of this problem for the coalition is that they knew and understood what they wanted to do and they went ahead and did it. The states are arguing very strongly that the Commonwealth should take up its responsibilities. If Mr Williams got his way, the states would pull out of funding those cases and it would cost the federal government much more to run their own program. We see in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) the coalition emerging from the shadowlands and into a bit of sunlight. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the election last year, the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard), when asked about his vision of Australia and his role for Australians, used the words `comfortable and relaxed' about our present, our past and our future. He was giving the impression that, if the coalition were elected, people could be relaxed and comfortable. That is quite fascinating, because this government is probably the most radical government that we have seen in this century. That may sound contradictory, because the impression they would try to give is that they are somehow for no change. The impression given at the election was that the only two points of difference between the coalition and Labor were on industrial relations and Telstra. It was a `me too' election.

SPEECH.PARA: In actual practice, the government is really quite radical. I want to go through some of those radical areas so that people can fully understand the degree of difference. I am actually quite convinced that members of the government themselves do not even understand how radical the government is. There is always a danger in public office of believing your own propaganda. At times, I think government members are victims of that.

Firstly, I want to talk about the supposed budget deficit. We had an awful lot of hype in the lead‐up to the budget or immediately after the election about the state of the nation's accounts and affairs. We had projections of various levels, such as $6 billion, $8 billion and now $10 billion, of a supposed deficit. The implication from that was that somehow the previous government had overspent, wasted all this money and were leaving a debt in dollars to be passed on. We all know, as did all the economists, that the differences being talked about were differences between projections and forecasts and actual events. As we know, if growth increases by more or less than one per cent per year, it will probably cost the budget, at the bottom line, one or two billion dollars. We all know that. That whole charade was basically about forecasts.

In January, the revised budget showed that the forecasts were out by $3 billion. That then makes a very interesting concept. We now have this whole new radical approach. Governments no longer budget on projections, make forecasts and then adjust them. Every time there is a variation to the forecast, it will be due to government mismanagement or waste or government expenditure. So there is no way that the current government can now escape the radical notion that the forecasts they made in August are their mistakes due to their incompetence and misspending. That is the impression they gave and that is the impression the Australian people now have.

But an even more radical approach has come forward in recent days from the Bureau of Statistics which, incidentally, will find life difficult with reduced budgets. They are, therefore, looking at ways of saving money. More importantly, they are suggesting a new method to measure the CPI or inflation which would actually discount a range of factors.

Expectations are that that will reduce the CPI effect by a minimum of one per cent per year and possibly greater. That may or may not be more accurate, who knows, but it is a radical change in the notion of how we treat our society, given that a whole range of activities are actually linked to the CPI. The amount pensioners can claim as income and the amount of assets they can have before being effected—all those payments and benefits—are linked to the CPI.

So this radical new government is now going to change the CPI and actually change the linkages. On one hand they will pretend this is no change. All they are doing really is adopting the figures of the Bureau of Statistics, but we actually know that what is being done is quite deliberate and simply radical.

Let us go through various sections of Australia and see what being comfortable and relaxed actually means to Australians now. Looking at older Australians, there have been radical changes to superannuation whereby people who have been retrenched over the age of 55 are now facing a very real problem: having to deem their rollover—and in many cases it is quite a small amount—for up to nine years post‐retrenchment. These people are looking for work and would rather be in a job, would rather have a decent income, but they do not have a choice. Now the government is seeing them as fair prey for revenue raising. That is a very radical shift.

Looking at the nursing home system, there has been a cut in budget expenditure of $500 million over four years—half a billion dollars is being ripped out of the expenditure budgets and the appropriations for residential aged care. Of course, there is talk of an up-front fee. Notionally the figure that has been talked about is $26,000. Anybody who talks to the industry knows that figure does not work. The cost of providing a nursing home bed varies between $50,000 and $75,000, not $26,000. There is no way the industry can provide new beds on an up-front fee of $26,000, given the supposed notional maximum deduction from that of $13,000 over four years.

So the fact is there has been a radical change to residential aged care, which has been in place in Australia for a very long time. Previous conservative governments put up capital grants and support for people in residential aged care facilities. This new government, the one that is comfortable and relaxed and the one the people should feel comfortable about, has changed decades and decades of practice in the support of aged Australians. That is a radical change and it has enormous implications.

I do not think the opposition members know just yet how serious it is. They will find out eventually when they find the up‐front fees being asked for are $80,000, $100,000 or $120,000 and that, out of those people who are seeking accommodation, the ones with the most money will get the access.

That will put pressure on families in terms of having their parents not going into a nursing home, on finding the money to put their parents into a nursing home. How do they raise it? Do they mortgage their own houses so their parents can get in when they do not have assets? The idea that somehow people with no money will get in is a nonsense. How can they? Who is going to pay? Who is going to provide the capital?

On the figures that have been provided, on the charges that are involved, there is no way a nursing home can have extra funds to provide beds for people who cannot make a contribution. So the idea of equity, which has been a longstanding Australian principle, will be gone. That is a radical change. As I said, it will be some time before those opposite understand it.

Similarly, there are proposals for home and community care. Take, for example, neighbour A, where people in the community volunteer to visit people who are living at home by themselves, who are frail, who are aged, who have a disability, who are housebound or who are isolated. We have volunteers who go and visit them to give them company or who may take them out for a picnic, for a drive, to visit a shopping centre or anything at all. It gives them some social experience and a bit more depth to their life.

The proposal now for home and community care is that user pays—there will be a charge of 20 per cent. This means that a person who requires those services is going to have to pay to get a volunteer to come and talk to them. What a nonsense. What a radical change. The whole idea of volunteering is that people come because they want to, the people they are visiting are being visited because people want to visit them, not because they are being paid to. The nature of the whole home and community care program, the future of how we treat our people who are more isolated, is being transformed—again, in ignorance.

We are seeing the changes as well in the health system, which is going to have a profound effect on older Australians. So those older Australians who felt the election of a coalition government would give them some comfort, some relaxation and some stability, if you like, are experiencing a very rude shock because, as I said earlier, they really have the most radical government in many decades.

Let us look at the other end of the spectrum at young Australians. Many young Australians voted for the coalition government in 1996. What have they found? Are there any reasons for them to be comfortable and relaxed? There are not many at all. If you look at what they are experiencing, there is the absolute debacle in Austudy. I and all members of the parliament—both in opposition and in government—have been besieged by young people either in university or in full-time education or by those about to enter it suddenly being told that they will not be entitled to income support.

I have had young women in my office in tears in the last week absolutely desperate to try to be educated but cannot be because of their family circumstances—a family breakdown, income, relationships or emotional dysfunctionality between their parents. One young woman in particular is absolutely distressed and will not be able to enrol in full-time education. She will have to change her whole life direction, a radical change for her. Why? She has to change it because of a radical change to the system.

She was entitled to support. She needs support to become a productive and worthwhile member of our community. She requires support to become educated. She will not get it. So she will be forced to sink back into working in a position for which she is overendowed with both intellect and ability. She will not be able to develop her skills because this government is saying, `You don't deserve the support.'

Overall, we are looking at $3½ billion worth of cuts to higher education in the next four years. It is important to understand in amongst this that the growth rate of higher education was an important factor in the previous decade. The introduction of higher education charges and fees was to allow it to grow faster.

In the HECS system, there is currently over $3 billion of accumulated contributions that have been paid off by people as they reached a reasonable income level. In other words, they were paying towards their education. So the idea that somehow it was taxpayers who were funding this, as we heard in the parliament yesterday from the Prime Minister, was always a lie. It was always untrue because the introduction of HECS allowed a faster rate of growth for higher education than other forms of expenditure because the people who were benefiting were contributing to it in a major way. That was a constructive and positive change.

BREAK.PARA: In Australia we will see Australian universities costing more than full‐fee paying universities in America. We will see the idea of access to education as a matter for the elite or for the privileged. Within five or six years, we are looking at being desperately short of science teachers. What a nonsense! For a country of our educational standards, for a country of our expectations and living standards, to be able to sit and predict a shortage of science teachers in our high schools is an appalling indictment.

What has been part of the cause for it? Part of it was a grab for money, a lifting in HECS charges on the grounds that science would be a higher paying occupation. That never was true and never will be true, but it told young Australians a very clear message: do not go to science. So they are not. Universities around Australia are seeing dropping enrolments across the board, but particularly in areas where the higher education charge increases have been most affected.

So we are seeing $3½ billion worth of cuts across the higher education sector. Who is carrying it? The young people are carrying it, like that woman in my office last Friday afternoon who was in tears and back there again on Monday morning in tears asking me desperately, `What can I do?' I said, `I'm sorry. I can't help. The government's made a decision. It's been through the parliament and the rules are being applied. There is no answer.' That is who is paying for it. That is where the savings are coming from.

When you hear the government boasting about its savings, it is important to think of whose savings they are. They are the savings of people who have nothing. They are the savings of people who now do not get support, but these short-term savings will provide very long-term costs, and that is the radical change.

We also have a new definition of families for people on benefits of any form. We understand that people who rent get some rent support in various circumstances, but we now have a new system. If two single people share accommodation and pay the same amount as they would pay if they were renting singularly, they now get a different rent allowance. They are now seen as being a new kind of family.

We suddenly have this new notion that, because they pay the same money whether it be $50 a week each in a unit by themselves or in accommodation which they share, somehow they are a family and have lower costs. This is a whole new radical change to how we see families. I can see a new thing in the future for taxation or other benefits for people who share accommodation and are treated as a new family unit, an economic family. It is a pretty radical notion, but it has actually been done. It is happening right now. Rent assistance has been reduced right now.

We look also then at the changes to families in terms of this new government. We look at things like housing, access to public housing. The enormous changes being proposed there will rip away completely the capital program so that the state housing departments will rely solely on rent and some kind of market relationship. It is an enormous change but, at the same time, they are also removing the Commonwealth's role in planning and direction. So access to housing for young people will disappear. Forget it.

What will happen to the subprogram supported accommodation, which has been part of the housing portfolio? In this new world the Commonwealth abdicates responsibility, all those special programs where the Commonwealth has put in tied funds and special funds in the housing programs will disappear. What is more, there will be a transfer to the states of a range of other services. This is not about federalism; this is about abdication. So we are seeing the most radical shifts in responsibility ever imagined.

The transfer to the state governments of all health, education, aged care and disabilities is across the board and the Commonwealth will then ignore them. A good example of this was the Star program—the students at risk program—which was a Commonwealth initiative. It was an extra program where extra funds were provided to education departments to help young people from dysfunctional families who were at risk of homelessness to stay in education, to give them a chance in life.

The program ran for some years. It was a very small program in money terms and its review was done towards the end of 1995. It was a very good review. It was a very good program with enormous potential. Where has it gone? It has been mainstreamed, broadbanded. It has gone. Now around Australia those teachers who taught in those programs and who taught those young people are saying, `We ain't got nothing to help them with.' Schools no longer have the resources to give the special needs and special support to the young people whose chances in life are so much affected by the fact that their family is dysfunctional.

Marriage breakdowns, sexual abuse and domestic violence all impact so much on young people. We were trying to give support to them because they needed special support, but that is going. So when we start talking about youth suicides in the future, when we start talking about greater family breakdowns, make no mistake: it does not happen by accident. These things happen in a society where other things are happening. If you rip away the support of people who need help, you get some damage.

Sure, there may be a lower budget deficit; there may be a lower national debt in three, four and five years time in dollars; but let me tell you the debt of damaged people we are going to carry into the next generation is going to be enormous. It is growing every day. In our offices we are seeing the anger, the rage, the frustration and the alienation day in and day out. Every day I am getting phone calls and receiving letters. It is going to lead to a huge cost. If one wants to look at what it eventually amounts to, one should look at America where there is so little support for people with difficulties.

What we are heading for is the Americanisation of Australia. That is a radical change because we have never had their notions of social justice; we have had a much more European notion. We are seeing Australia being radicalised and transformed to an American system whereby it is every man, woman and kid for yourselves. If you are big and strong, bright and clever, and come from a wealthy family then you will probably do pretty well. But if you are not that is life, folks, because that is the American model. The right to fail for those who are less able; the right to suffer for those who are less strong; and the right to starve for those who are less wealthy—that is the American model. For us it is a radical shift. The idea of us being comfortable and relaxed about that is disgraceful.

That is just a few examples. I have many more examples in all the other areas of budget expenditure which are equally applicable. This government is the most radical government in decades, and those opposite will eventually come to understand that. (Time expired)
