TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Main Committee that we have present in the gallery this morning Mr Tabernnang Timeon, a member of the Parliament of Kiribati. On behalf of the committee, I would like to welcome you to our Main Committee room and hope that you enjoy your stay with us.
—Hear, hear!

DEBATE.TITLE:
APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97
APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I add my felicitations to the honourable gentleman from Kiribati. I rise to speak on the additional appropriation bills that are before the Main Committee today and, predictably enough, I wish to wish to turn my attention to the transport and regional development sections of the additional appropriations. The additional amount to be appropriated with respect to the Department of Transport and Regional Development is in the vicinity of $367 million, and all but about $3 million of that relates to the proposed privatisation and associated rearrangements of Australian National.

SPEECH.PARA: It is with some pleasure that I am able to get up here and speak about Australian National because, unfortunately, we have not as yet had an opportunity in this parliament to debate the government's plans with respect to Australian National. It is opportune today to consider the proposals that are, in part, dealt with in these appropriation bills with respect to the future of our national rail line.

The Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) announced on 24 November on Channel 9's Sunday program that the government proposed to seek to privatise Australian National either in toto or in bits. It is rather ironic that the minister, after having criticised the former government—he attacked the former Keating government in June last year during a ministerial statement debate on aviation safety for not coming to the House with major policy statements but rather making major announcements through press conferences or statements on TV—for this sort of behaviour, then went ahead and did exactly that himself. He chose not to use the forms of the House to make an announcement of the magnitude that is involved with the Australian National privatisation but, rather, sought to make the announcement on the Sunday program.

The minister has made three ministerial statements with respect to aviation safety but none with respect to the future of the Australian rail industry. It is long overdue that he come into the House and justify the position that he is adopting.

On 15 April last year, the Chairman of Australian National wrote to the minister indicating that the proposed deficit for Australian National for the 1995-96 year, instead of being a projected $26 million, would end up being as high as $106 million. As a result, the minister established the Brew inquiry into the finances and general situation of Australian National.

It is important to point out that substantial losses or deficits are not uncommon at Australian National. In fact, in the last year of conservative government under Malcolm Fraser, Australian National lost $106 million, which is $192 million in today's dollars; and in the preceding year—given that 1982-83 was affected by the drought—the loss was $72 million or $146 million in today's figures. So there have been substantial losses in the past, including under conservative governments with National Party transport ministers.

It is important to remember that community service obligations are built into Australian National's obligations. Therefore, some losses will be inevitable, because governments impose on Australian National certain requirements that may not necessarily be capable of being profitable. Labor introduced a range of reforms into Australia's rail system. As the minister has pointed out, the number of workers in Australian National dropped from 13,000 in 1978 to a little under 3,000 now. But what he fails to point out is that the same thing happened across all the state systems as massive changes in work practices and technology reduced the need for labour in the system.

The former government also introduced National Rail as a stand‐alone interstate rail freight operator. It was effectively forced by the states to separate that out of Australian National in order to get the state involvement and the state track involvement with National Rail. This left Australian National with something of a rump with three major passenger operations—the Ghan, the Indian Pacific and the Overland; two major workshop facilities; and a range of other facilities including Tasrail and intrastate freight in South Australia.

Australian National had a bad year in 1992-93, largely due to the recession, but in 1993-94 it had its best year for a long time. 1994-95 was not quite so good but, nonetheless, it was still much better than 1991-92 and 1992-93. So the criticisms made of the former minister, Laurie Brereton, that he was fiddling while Rome burned and that Australian National was going out backwards financially at the time of his administration are simply untrue and totally unfounded.

Australian National's finances have deteriorated—there is no question about that—although there is debate about the magnitude. We managed to obtain an executive summary of the Brew report, courtesy of a return to order motion in the Senate. The minister still has not been formally tabled the report of the Brew inquiry in the parliament but it has been provided to the Senate inquiry.

Mr Brew found that the losses for 1995-96 would be of the magnitude of $130 million to $148 million and that National Rail's creation had `made it almost impossible for Australian National to operate profitably'. He found that Australian National had a total debt of over $800 million and described Australian National as overstaffed and overcapitalised. He recommended that the government proceed with the former government's plan to establish a separate track infrastructure body to own and operate the rail track; that National Rail should be set up on a purely commercial basis, which it was due to be anyway; and that Australian National's operations and infrastructure be sold off either to state governments or private operators, potentially in bits.

On 12 September, a press release from Australian National came to light, which indicated that it was already in the process of starting to sell off some of its businesses. The minister went through a rather convoluted explanation for this saying that this was all as a result of actions of the former government, so do not blame him. But at the same time he was alleging that the former government had done nothing to stem the flow of financial problems at AN. Both of those comments were entirely contradictory.

On 26 September it was revealed by the opposition that Mr Brew, shortly after having presented his report, had in some way become entangled with a consortium called the Great Southern Railway which was promoted by Macquarie Bank. Although it is not clear exactly what the nature of his relationship was there, he was very quickly disowned by the government in regard to that connection. What is obvious is that, during the course of developing his report and his analysis, Mr Brew was contemplating his future and the possibilities of further work associated with a private operator who may acquire AN. So it is no great surprise that he recommended the privatisation of AN, and obviously he saw that as a possible means of profit.

When you actually read the Brew report itself, you see that it is a very narrow exercise. It is essentially an accounting exercise only. It takes no consideration of the broader factors involved in operating the rail system that AN is charged with operating. It is something that has only recently become obvious because we have only just got hold of a copy of the Brew report. But it certainly does not do anything beyond look at the balance sheet and the profit and loss account of all of the individual sections of AN. It does not look at the bigger picture of how they fit together, what purposes they are there for and how they function.

As I have indicated, on 24 November the minister announced his privatisation strategy and that he would sell AN either in bits or as a single entity. He stated that AN's total losses were $250 million for 1995-96. This had gone up from $26 million, to $106 million, to between $135 million and $148 million, and now to $250 million. He also announced a so-called $2 billion package to save AN. Both of these figures were entirely fictitious. The $250 million included a figure of $140 million for one-off abnormal items, about $116 million of which related to asset revaluations.

Now, a decline in the value of AN's assets is not a trivial issue, but it is a world apart from an operating loss which can be expected to continue unless something is done. So $140 million was for one-off abnormals and $40 million was an ongoing Commonwealth subsidy to AN which, in effect, is a community service obligation component. It is there as a recognition that AN is effectively obliged to continue operating certain services which are unprofitable and unlikely to become profitable. The actual operating loss for 1995-96 was $69 million—only $14 million higher than the equivalent loss for the previous year.

The situation is not good. Clearly, it needs to be improved. But the minister grossly exaggerated the problems and grossly exaggerated the extent of the financial difficulties of AN in order to justify selling it off. It is important to recognise that rail is subsidised virtually throughout the world, in most cases directly by government. In the case of the United States, the main long‐haul passenger rail system there, Amtrak, is subsidised to the tune of over $1 billion a year by the public sector. So that is the context in which we need to see this situation.

The $2 billion package was also largely fictitious. An amount of $200‐odd million of this $2 billion consisted of funds already allocated in the budget, including for things such as Track Australia—as it was originally called and then subsequently was changed to the National Rail Infrastructure Authority—which is to own and operate the track. The new government had actually cut the funding proposed for that body which was presented in the previous federal budget under the Keating government.

An amount of $50 million was allocated notionally for environmental clean-up and I notice that surfaced again in the additional appropriations. The basis of this assessment was a notional examination of all Australian National sites to determine how much it would cost to do an environmental clean-up of all sites if they had to be sold. No matter what the minister is proposing to do, I think it is fairly unlikely we will see a situation in the immediate future where all sites will cease to be used for railway purposes. Therefore, in my view, the notion that this $50 million has to be paid soon is essentially fictitious.

BREAK.PARA: Roughly $800 million of the $2 billion package refers to Australian National's debt. This is ludicrous because that debt is already an obligation of the Commonwealth. We are talking here about a pure accounting exercise where the Commonwealth is saying, `We will assume direct responsibility for it.' The Commonwealth as the sole owner of Australian National already had direct responsibility for it in effect. It has simply shifted it from one heading to another. To suggest that some big, marvellous thing has been done here is ridiculous.

And similarly with superannuation where there is an amount of $580 million for superannuation liabilities. What has happened over many years is that Australian National fully funds its super obligations by paying that into consolidated revenue, and the super obligations are paid on an ongoing basis by the Commonwealth out of consolidated revenue. Because of the fact that privatisation may produce a bunching of superannuation payment obligations by making all the workers redundant—that is a choice the minister has made—the Commonwealth has to bear that superannuation obligation. The key point is that AN has already paid for it. It has already contributed the funds for it.

There is also no mention of AN's assets in this so-called $2 billion package, which at the last count were valued at over $1 billion. We are supposed to be spending all this money, but the government is not spending it. There is no recognition that, if they are going to privatise and do it properly, they should reap substantial income. There are very few real expenditures in the proposals other than things like the rather paltry amount of $20 million for regional adjustment, which will only be a drop in the ocean in terms of the problems that are likely to be caused for places such as Port Augusta, other parts of South Australia and Tasmania as a result of the changes that will flow from AN's privatisation. It is interesting to see the comments of some of the local figures and representative bodies on these issues.

What this all demonstrates is that the crisis at AN is three‐quarters phoney. There is a set of problems. Clearly, a strategy needs to be put in place to get it a bit more back on track. But it has been grossly exaggerated in order to justify the government's desire, for ideological reasons, to get it off the budget and to get rid of any Commonwealth commitment to rail in the budget. That is why it is occurring. This phoney crisis is being beaten up in order to justify it.

The best illustration of this is the government's proposal to sell its share of National Rail. National Rail has reduced the interstate freight deficit from $350 million to $50 million within the space of four or five years. So, even though AN has deteriorated, the total Commonwealth rail picture looked at as a whole has improved significantly over that time because National Rail has done what it intended to do, which was massively improve interstate freight operations. That is the evidence given by the department of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development to a Senate committee in September last year.

This illustrates the hypocrisy of the government's position. Their only justification for selling AN is that its finances are bleeding it. Yet National Rail, which is broadly on track to commercial viability, as it was intended to be after five years, is going to be sold with no justification. The real reason is to get the rail system out of government, to get rid of community service obligations and government involvement and to take money away from budget obligations.

It is also worth noting that the Grants Commission has provided evidence to the Senate inquiry about the likely consequences of the privatisation of Australian National for grants to the states. Senator Abetz said that Tasmania would get $10 million per year in additional grants. The maximum possible that the Grants Commission estimates is $5 million. For South Australia, it estimates a range which starts at minus $0.4 million—that is, minus $400,000—up to $16 million per year. So there has been a bit of shifting and slipping on that front as well.

The potential consequences arising from the privatisation of Australian National are these. About 2,600-odd jobs are under threat. It is very difficult to suggest that all those jobs will remain. In fact, it is reasonable to predict that a lot of them will disappear. The three passenger services—the Ghan, the Overlander and the Indian Pacific—are under threat. The current route that the Indian Pacific takes is also under threat, which should be a matter of some interest to the member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), who is affected by it. If it is re‐routed through Melbourne, clearly many of the areas that he represents will be disadvantaged as a result.

The grain lines in South Australia are under threat, which potentially impacts on wheat farmers in those areas. Tasrail, which is not far short of break even, is clearly under threat. Many of the economic entities that use Tasrail—the industries in Tasmania that make use of those services—will potentially have their transport costs increased, which may threaten their viability. The Fingal Valley coalmines are a classic example of relatively marginal operations that may be put out of business if the government is not careful.

It has been estimated by the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics that $15 million per year would need to be spent on Tasmanian roads if Tasrail is closed down. Yet the Tasrail deficit is currently only about $6 or $7 million per year. So that shows the economic logic behind privatising or closing down Tasrail.

AN could be sold in bits, which is a serious problem, because that may involve cherry picking and competitors for things such as buying the workshops, asset stripping them and closing them down and diminishing competition. There may be no further subsidies to things such as passenger services, which places, as I have indicated, the Indian Pacific under threat. There is also the loss of integration benefits and economies of scope that come from having a unified railway.

The key theme in all this, and the one I will turn to in conclusion, is that there is no overall strategy for rail. We have a fire sale and that is it. All this government is doing is flogging off things. It does not matter whether it is in bits or who will buy it and what they will do with it. They want to get rid of it, get it off the balance sheet and the budget and not worry about what will happen.

We oppose the privatisation of Australian National. Most importantly, our strongest objection to the government's policy is that there is no broad strategic vision for the future of rail. There is no vision about the future of the passenger services or the future of Tasrail and the services it provides to important industries in Tasmania. There is no vision for the role that the grain lines play for farmers in South Australia. There is no vision for the future of Port Augusta as an important regional centre and a rail infrastructure centre in South Australia. There is no vision for the strategic framework in transport and the relationship and balance between road and rail. There is no vision for the intermodal connections between road, rail and shipping. There is none of that; there is simply a fire sale.

These are the key issues. What we need in this country is a comprehensive national transport strategy that looks at the total task and the total role of transport. It is important to note, as I noted in the Main Committee on another matter last night, that this government sees transport as a cost. It does not see it as anything else. It is a cost. It does not recognise that the transport industry is a major exporter, particularly through aviation and shipping, that the transport industry is a creator and provider of thousands and thousands of skilled and mostly well‐paid jobs and that it is, in essence, the arteries of our national economy. It plays a critical role, yet for the narrow‐minded, short-sighted and ignorant view of the government and the minister it is simply a cost to the people they see as their core constituency.

The people who will suffer as a result of this view are particularly the workers in Australian National and the direct users of the services of Australian National. In Tasmania, it will be the users of the Tasrail freight services. There are also the grain growers in South Australia and the passengers using the interstate passenger services. More broadly, it will affect the Australian community generally. The rail services that Australian National provides are an important part of the total transport picture. Australian National needs reform and improvement, but it should not be just broken up, sold off and flogged off, with the government pulling right out of any direct involvement in rail or having any strategic vision for the future of rail. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to comment on a number of areas of the government's performance in discussing these appropriation bills before the committee today. I would particularly like to talk about higher education, the government's proposed work for the dole scheme, the proposed abolition of the Commonwealth Employment Service, the government's scheme to increase costs in nursing homes, the abolition of the Commonwealth dental program and the ridiculous delays that the government is causing in getting a solution to the problem of Sydney airport. These are all major issues that affect my electorate of Watson.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has certainly stuffed up on higher education charges. Rather than striving to improve the level of education, the government is making access to higher education more difficult with its cuts to university funding and increases in HECS charges. We have already seen the outcome of this in my electorate, with the axing of courses at the St George campus of the University of New South Wales. Because of the government's funding cuts, the University of New South Wales intends closing down that campus. The state minister for education, the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) and I have been lobbying actively to try to get the University of New South Wales or the University of Wollongong to keep this campus open. Neither of them can do it without additional funds from the Commonwealth.

This campus fulfilled a vital need for the population of south-west Sydney. That is demonstrated by the fact that 70 per cent of the students in the primary education course at that campus came from the St George and Sutherland region. Now those students will have to travel further afield to complete their courses. The state minister, the member for Barton and I are hopeful that the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (Senator Vanstone) might see some way of ensuring that this campus does not close.

The effects of the government's policies on higher education will mean that, by the year 2000, each institution will have had a 15 per cent funding cut across the board. Increases to HECS charges will also have a detrimental effect on the number of students from my electorate studying science and engineering due to the government's differential charging system.

While the Labor Party was in government, we invested heavily in creating a high quality education system. We saw the number of students in higher education rise over the 13-year period of our office from approximately 340,000 people in higher education when we came into government to 600,000 when we went out. That is nearly a 50 per cent increase in the number of Australians who were able to access higher education.

BREAK.PARA: With the Liberal Government's present measures, we will see less incentive for students from working class areas to go to university. We will be going back to the 1950s and 1960s. Maybe that is where the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) felt comfortable and relaxed, but it certainly is not the place for Australia in the 1990s. By the year 2000, when we will host the Olympics, we hope to be able to say that Australia is the clever country. How will we do that if the government is being so stupid as to make access to higher education as difficult as possible?

The government has also put another disincentive in the way of students with its monumental mistake by Minister Vanstone over the means test for Austudy. This has denied funding to thousands of students. It is a joke that the government says it prides itself on administrative ability while it cannot even get a simple piece of paperwork right. All the minister can do is think up phoney examples of bludgers in the system, as she called them, such as the Wright family. She could not even get that right, because that was a fiction.

For most of her work, the Prime Minister seemed to reward this minister with a bottle of champagne. I think the reward she got the other day from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) of a bottle of vinegar was more appropriate to the approach that this minister has taken with higher education and the ability of young people to go to university.

With universities going back to work next week, it will be a sad commentary on the system to know that it took so long for Senator Vanstone to recognise the obvious deficiencies in the Austudy means test. She says that she is sorry. She might be sorry, but it is a pretty sorry state for those young people who did not pursue a career through university because they could not afford to go when they had been stripped of Austudy. It is a bit too late for them to find out now that they can get Austudy, because the universities have accepted other people to fill the places that these young people would have been able to take. A number of parents in my electorate have complained to my office and me personally about the problems that this has created for their families. This is particularly so for migrant parents, who put a very high price and regard on education as a method for their children to get out of the low income jobs that many of them had. Senator Vanstone's approach to this has been deplorable.

In many areas, the government has been deplorable. What they want to do with employment is another example of their failure to come to grips with the problems in Australian society. Their idea of a quick fix for unemployment by their scheme of making some people work for the dole is really bankrupt. What sort of a solution is this to getting the long-termed unemployed back to work? The long-term unemployed need to acquire skills. When the Labor government was in office, we had programs that helped—

PARA.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the interruption of the division in the House of Representatives, I was saying how important it is that people who are the long-term unemployed are provided with skills to help them get back into employment. One of the programs the government cut was Skillshare, which was a very important program for giving unemployed people the ability to find work. An analysis was done by the government's favourite economics gurus, Access Economics, and that showed that Skillshare was successful as it made a net contribution to the federal budget. In fact, each year's operation of the Skillshare network created an average net gain to the budget over three years of about $500 per participant.

BREAK.PARA: The government, one would think, has an obligation to make sure the unemployed have access to schemes which guarantee not just something to take them off the unemployment roles but the acquisition of skills and training which will help them keep jobs. It is clear that the Howard government offers no solution to address unemployment, and the work for the dole scheme is just a very inefficient method of making some people work for the dole and other people not. There is no universality, no reciprocal obligation. It really is a scheme like the Prime Minister decried in the election campaign of a program to have people painting rocks.

Funding for job programs that have been redirected from the soon to be abolished CES to private and public sector case managers will also mean a potential rise in unemployment and discrimination of migrants and Aboriginal groups who fear they will be avoided by private job agencies. There is a great concern in my electorate, especially in the city of Canterbury, about this change in the way unemployed people find work, particularly as in the city of Canterbury there are people from over 132 different nations.

Canterbury Skillshare has had its budget cut dramatically causing courses to be cut by half and redundancies within the organisations. This has resulted in decreasing staff morale as people do not know if they have a job after June. It also means that they are going to turn clients away because of the uncertainty that this will cause in that organisation. So much for the Prime Minister's offer to make people feel relaxed and comfortable. He certainly has not made the unemployed people in my electorate, or those trying to provide a service to them, feel relaxed and comfortable at all.

Those who have been the hardest hit and the most disadvantaged are those wanting to undertake English language classes. It is cruel of the government to deny people the opportunity to learn the language of their new country. Surely this is a deterrent to new settlers as `learning a common language', according to the government, is the glue to a cohesive nation. If we cannot allow people to take up that glue, how do they become part of the nation?

Also, the impact of the new changes with the one stop shop in the welfare area may not take into account the different cultural mixes of some areas. Surely a service needs to be tailored to the clientele. One of the offices that stands to be affected by this in my electorate is the Campsie office of the Department of Social Security. This office is much overworked and understaffed and, according to the 1991 census, 50 per cent of those who use the office come from a non-English speaking background. This means they have very different needs from the people in areas such as the Prime Minister's electorate of Bennelong. Often interpreters have to be used with these clients which means that each service takes longer.

Secondly, most of the clients like to be dealt with face to face because they have problems understanding some of the administrative procedures and their lower language skills make it difficult to understand conversations over the telephone. With the establishment of a one stop shop, the staff at the Campsie Department of Social Security will have to become, unfortunately, jacks of all trades, and that means they will become masters of none. We will find there will be a lot of misunderstanding and confusion, not to mention the lowering once again of the morale of the staff servicing both the CES and the Department of Social Security in my electorate.

Another area which also concerns my constituents is the government's disgraceful attack on people wanting to go into nursing homes. The electorate of Watson has the fifth highest number of pensioners over the age of 65 in the Sydney metropolitan area. These people rely on government services and the Labor government provided services for those people.

In the first years of the Howard government, increases in the costs for the home and community care scheme and the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are hitting these pensioners hard. The government is treating senior citizens as second-class citizens, and these are the people who went through the Depression, who fought for this country and who thought that they could at least rely upon the government to help them in their old age. The entry fee to nursing homes is really putting these people's lives at great risk. It is clear that the government has a lack of concern for the wellbeing of older Australians.

My electorate office has received many phone calls and letters from the aged in my electorate regarding the changes to the nursing home arrangements. One elderly woman in particular who lives with her husband and unmarried son was very worried about what the nursing home entry charges will mean and asked for it all to be explained in plain English but, if you try to ring up the office of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and ask them, they have no idea. Indeed, when the opposition spokesperson asked the minister to explain this in the House, once again, the minister had no idea.

So if the minister herself only goes on with platitudes, how can we put at rest the worries of older Australians in their 70s and 80s who may need to go into a nursing home? Unfortunately, the government has a very bad record of taking an interest in older Australians, particularly older Australians who do not have very many assets of their own.

One of the concerns of my electorate was the way the government axed the Commonwealth dental program. This was a good program introduced by the Labor government in 1993 to help low income earners and pensioners receive better dental care. Before that program was introduced, the only dental care that pensioners and health card holders received was teeth extraction. We wanted to have a better program that allowed people to get dental care that they could not afford.

It is interesting that, while the Prime Minister is not really interested in this, some people on the government side are. The member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) was quoted in the Penrith Sun News pictorial some time ago as admitting that `governments sometimes made the wrong decisions', when talking about the Commonwealth dental program. He knows it was wrong to get rid of this program. It is unfortunate that the government wants to ensure that those 500,000 pensioners and unemployed people who were receiving dental care under this program no longer get it. The people who went to the Canterbury Dental Clinic in my electorate will now have to wait up to three years for treatment.

Bishop Michael Challen from the Brotherhood of St Laurence wrote to me expressing his concern at the cessation of this program. He said that, because we live in an age where appearance is becoming more and more important, we are also condemning disadvantaged Australians to a second-class existence in terms of other opportunities for employment.

I would like to know what the government says to these people now. What it says, as we all know, is that under this government there are not any real opportunities for disadvantaged people to have employment opportunities. The government is axing programs that provided skills for these disadvantaged and is axing programs that gave them access to employment services. The government is coming up with nothing more than the Prime Minister's crisis management approach of saying, `We're under a lot of attack about what was happening to Senator Woods. We better try to deflect people and the news. So we will come up with a work for the dole scheme.' It is cheap, populist stuff driven by polls; but it does nothing at all to help the unemployed. As Minister Vanstone said, if the government cannot solve the unemployed problem, if it does not have a solution to the unemployed problem; where are they? Where they are is in a lot of trouble.

The final issue I would like to raise is the question of Sydney airport. This is another example of this government coming out with platitudes—not being able to put their money where their mouth is, not being to make a final decision on Sydney airport and not being able to give some certainty to the people who live around Sydney about what is going to happen with this monstrosity in their backyards.

We had the Prime Minister once again saying that people ought to feel relaxed and comfortable, but I can tell you that the three quarters of a million people who are affected by Sydney airport do not feel relaxed and comfortable at all. They felt particularly unrelaxed and uncomfortable when everybody thought the Sydney airport issue had been settled: the previous Labor government had decided that we were going to build an airport at Badgerys Creek; an EIS had been done; and everything seemed to be settled there. But then after the election the government comes up with a proposal for an airport at Holsworthy. So much for bringing the Australian people into their confidence prior to the election, because that would have done the coalition harm in the electorate of Hughes and in that part of south-west Sydney.

After the election the government comes up with this proposition to have an airport at Holsworthy. Twelve months out we still have not seen that proposition put to bed; we still have not seen the government recognise the stupidity of building an airport on what was a field firing range and an area that has gullies and hills in it. Maybe the government has some piece of new science that allows them to press a button and all the old bombs on the range will explode, the hills will implode and all of a sudden we will have this flat area that will allow them to build an airport.

It is somewhat like the naive dreams of previous Liberal governments in the 1950s and 1960s of creating dams using nuclear weapons. That might have been the sort of level of stupidity that has this government thinking about turning the field firing range at Holsworthy into an airport site. Like many of the other answers that this government has to important issues in Australian society, it is a quick fix that will not work.

I think that these appropriation bills are an opportunity for members to seriously look at the shortcomings of this government and to seriously look at what needs to happen in Australia. As we come up to the turn of the century, we should be a country that is able to look outward; we should be a country that has great wealth; and we should be able to share that wealth with the people who live here.

Unfortunately, the response of the government is to wind back government services. This government tries to blame it all on the opposition for the sins of the previous government. They say it was pretty terrible of us to leave a hole in the budget, but now they have managed to have their own $2.7 billion black hole—a black hole that Treasurer Costello cannot blame on the previous government. It is his own little black hole. He is going to ensure in the next budget that is due later this year that there is further winding back of government services.

The truth is that Australians are happy to pay taxes if they get value for their money. We must realise in a country the size of this that, if we do not have government providing infrastructure and services in a country as sparse as Australia, the first people to lose will be those in the country. And when the country suffers, the city suffers. We have to approach this in a national perspective. The government's current policies of turning everything back are just wasted. They are mean spirited; they are short-sighted; and they are not in the best interests of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the discussion of the two appropriation bills Nos 3 and 4, the views I want to put are views that relate to the harshness of the government's policies and the impact that they have upon the regions which I represent, the Hunter and the Central Coast. Overall, one can see across the matrix of government policies an attack on regional Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The very first action by the government was the abolition of the Department of Housing and Regional Development. Housing particularly is of extreme importance to regional Australia. The availability of low cost housing, the quality of the amenities available, and the movement of people to those lower cost areas are an important part of the function of regional economies; but, more than that, they are an important part of the lifestyle of Australians who live in regional Australia.

The regional development section of the Department of Housing and Regional Development was amalgamated with the Department of Transport and then abolished so fast that one could almost not comprehend that it could be achieved so quickly. I have never seen a department of government or a division of a department abolished so quickly as happened with regional development. It went from 226 people to three people, almost in a matter of days.

With the abolition of regional development went the hopes of the 40 regional development organisations that had been established, or were in the process of being established, right around Australia. The regional development organisations, to the areas that did not have them, brought the prospect of a say in government decision making and the hope that there would be some equity in the allocation of federal funds that were available. But, more important than that, they brought the prospect of the development of economic strategies for their particular regions.

If there is one issue that has angered country Australia so much, it has been the abolition of the Department of Housing and Regional Development and, subsequently, the regional development division of the Department of Transport and Regional Development. The promises that were made about helping regional Australia were thrown to the wind. We have to remember that the now government, during their period in opposition, denigrated the whole concept of regional development. They denigrated the development of regional development organisations. Despite the promises of a change and the tempering of their rhetoric as the election came closer, when they came into government they simply abolished that division and reneged on the undertakings given at election time.

But it goes much further than that. I hear members of the government talking about the money being spent on the black spots program under road expenditure. The black spots program is a relatively minor one as a component of total roads expenditure. The reality is that this government, in its first budget, chopped some $600 million from the national highway program.

It is poor solace to come back and say, as I heard the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) say this morning, `But we've got the black spots program back there.' Well, big deal! It is a few million dollars that is simply a fragment of the $600 million that was taken from the national highway program. The point is that 75 per cent of national highway expenditure is in country Australia. It has to be, because they are connecting roads outside the capital cities. So it is $600 million out and a few million dollars in—a betrayal of regional Australia.

If we turn to the programs and services that are available to regional Australia, I will talk specifically about the Hunter and the Central Coast of New South Wales—areas that I represent. The Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs office in Newcastle is closed. All service has to come from Sydney. That causes enormous inconvenience to people from right up through the Hunter region to the north coast who need the services of the department. The office at Newcastle, which had some 10 people, served not only the vicinity of Newcastle, but everywhere from the Hawkesbury virtually right through to the Tweed—to the Queensland border.

For country people, for regional Australia, simply having that service available is vastly different to a phone call or a fax to Sydney and then waiting until somebody gets around to responding. The department now says, `Yes, but we send out visiting teams.' Again, you wait for a visiting team of persons to come around, but they cannot make decisions. Newcastle had the ability to make decisions. That is the difference in the quality of service that was available to regional and that is no longer available. In the castigation of the former Labor government that goes on, in parrot fashion, from members of the government, what they cannot move away from is that they have damaged and attacked, or attacked and damaged, regional Australia.

One of the great credits of the former Labor government was that we regionalised federal government services. We took offices out to where the people who use those services were located. So we had a department of immigration office at Newcastle. The area office for the Department of Employment, Education and Training was in Newcastle, servicing an area from the Hawkesbury up to the Hastings River and west towards the Blue Mountains and, in some parts, beyond the Blue Mountains. It gave a regional service and it managed the Department of Employment, Education and Training offices, and all the CES offices, within the region.

The jobs that brings into regional Australia helps make up the greatest deficiency of all in regional Australia—the lack of tertiary employment, and this the boffins in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne do not comprehend. There is a world beyond Sydney Harbour Bridge. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) does not see it, because he is ensconced on the North Shore, at Kirribilli. He has no conception of what it means to be north of the Harbour Bridge in Sydney.

The retraction of services—closing CES offices, such as the Belmont office in my electorate, closing Medicare offices, closing the department of immigration office, further reducing the Australian Customs Service to what is really a token level in our region of New South Wales—impacts upon the people who most need those services. It impacts upon women, because the job opportunities that come from the regionalisation of those services mostly go to women in country Australia. The quality of service impacts upon the people who attend the Department of Social Security, where there is less quality, fewer people, poorer service and longer delays. Similarly, with CES offices closing and fewer people in the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, there is poorer service and longer delays, more discomfort and more trouble for people who have to use the services of that department.

We also now have, as I have said, a token Customs Service. Mr Deputy Chair, you are close to the coastline, in southern Queensland. You know how important the Customs Service is and how important the drug interdiction barrier is. We have 12 Customs officers guarding the New South Wales coastline from the Hawkesbury to the Tweed. At best, it is a token service. They get a bit of intelligence sometimes; they can make some recoveries. But in Newcastle, we have 695 foreign vessels coming into the port. There are about 1,450 vessel visits a year. When you take out the domestics—the local coastal visits—there are several hundred overseas ships coming in and out of that port, mostly from ports of north Asia, each year. So there are grand opportunities for disposal of contraband or any other products, be they drugs or whatever, because those vessels move up and down the coastline.

We hear from government members in the Hunter region what a wonderful job the government is doing for the Hunter, how they are really pushing forward with regional development. I have instanced some of the withdrawals, closures and damages that they have created in the Hunter. Let me add one more to the list: the building better cities program, stage 2. That was going to benefit Lake Macquarie City Council in my electorate. But $70 million was provided for Newcastle city under Stage 1 and that has meant the refurbishment of much of the foreshore of Newcastle and the old Honeysuckle rail goods yard. It is revitalising the city of Newcastle—and when you revitalise the city of Newcastle, you revitalise the surrounding regions.

The people who work in the cities are not necessarily the people who live in the cities. Newcastle is the workplace for thousands of people who live in the surrounding region, and vice versa. It is part of a regional economy, so it is $70 million going into that regional economy to upgrade infrastructure, to upgrade public amenity, to open up the foreshore, to construct new buildings and promote a rebirth of the dead heart of a city—a doughnut city, as we so often see in Western cities. Generating regrowth in the heart of the city throws a spreading benefit out to all the surrounding region, including the Central Coast, because it is all one economy. So the government, with great play, abolishes stage 2 of the building better cities program.

The same government, when in opposition, panned that program, ridiculed it. What they do not realise, because they have been captivated by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) and the Treasury‐speak of the Department of the Treasury, is that the building better cities program was really not about helping capital cities—though some of it was—but it was extending out into regional Australia. I am tired of this place hearing the kind of rhetoric coming out of ministers who are really picking up the doctrinaire Treasury line of economic rationalism.

We have to invest in regional Australia. The greatest investment in regional Australia is the national highway program. It links all of the capital cities, but also all of the regional locations, all the regional towns and centres, along the national grid, enabling Australians to get together, to trade together and share in the economic benefits that are available and the trade and commerce that has developed around it. The attack of the government on regional Australia has been very deeply felt in the region that I represent. That makes it all the more ludicrous to hear members of the government claiming what a wonderful government it is for regional Australia.

Interest rates have come down. But for small business they have come down less than half the amount that they have for home borrowers. As far as small businesses are concerned—it is one of the reasons behind the survey results that came out today—they do not have the muscle to negotiate with banks to get the kind of reductions that the banks are giving to other clients. Small businesses in regional Australia are getting a minuscule benefit and they do not have any muscle or bargaining power.

BREAK.PARA: The other thing about small business in regional Australia is that 48 per cent of small business does not employ anybody. I say to government members, `Where do you think this massive growth in employment is coming from when, say, 50 per cent of small businesses, in round figures, do not employ anybody?' They are just self‐traders. They are self‐employed people—an electrician, plumber, TV technician or whatever. They are trades people in some sort of service activity. So that means the other 50 per cent have to provide this massive explosion. But on what—on the basis of 1½ per pent reduction in interest rates, and in the context of contracting retail demand?

To appreciate what is happening one has only to talk to people in the large shopping centres who are being exploited unbelievably. But when we put a motion, as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) has done, on the Notice Paper seeking to introduce a bill to amend the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the provisions in respect of unconscionable conduct by landlords in major shopping centres, the government just stands with its hands behind its back and says, `Oh, but that's really a matter for negotiation and developing a code of practice'.

That does not help my constituents in the shopping centres located in my electorate. It certainly does not help them pay the bills when they are captive tenants and are being utterly exploited by landlords. Those tenants have sunk their redundancy package into a small business centre; they cannot get out and they cannot get any help from government. We are the opposition. We cannot pass laws. It is the government members opposite who have got the numbers and they have the power. When is government going to stop the rhetoric about small business and actually do something to help people in small business? I am tired of hearing tales of suffering from small retailers who have been driven to the wall by rapacious landlords in major shopping centres.

I want to turn to what is happening with Medicare and with health services. One can see as clear as crystal in the utterances coming from the government and the arrogance of the current Minister for Health and Family Services that this government is on the same strategy as the Fraser government when they lambasted what was then Medibank. They took the view that Medibank would be the ruination of fee for service and of the private hospital system. They built up expectations in the community's mind that something had to be done about Medibank, even though they had promised they would maintain it. They implicitly said, `We will maintain Medibank', as last year the coalition said, `We will maintain Medicare'.

Every time I speak in this House on this issue I am going to say this over and over and I will watch the faces opposite. Bit by bit, this government is seeking to pull away the pieces of Medicare in a strategy—on the same lines as were adopted by the Fraser government—that is designed to bring the Medicare system into disrepute to justify a privatised system of health care. Obviously the government wants our system to finish up along American lines where you have a two class system divided into those who can afford health care and those who cannot.

I want to make one point, and this is where the health funds at the moment have got caught. When those opposite were running that campaign about why you needed to be in a private health insurance fund, according to them it was because the quality of care in public hospitals was supposed to be abysmal. The message was that you could not possibly contemplate suddenly becoming ill and going into a public hospital with enormous wards containing 25 or 50 beds. We were told that a woman who is sick needed privacy and here she was lined up in a ward with 25 beds on one side and 25 beds on the other side. She would have no doctor of choice, would hear pans clanging, bottles banging, people coming and going. The message those opposite put out was that a person could not possibly cope with that standard of care in a public ward, and that was what Medibank was about.

The private health insurance funds built up their empires around the great media campaigns they conducted and linked to that was that you had to have a doctor of choice. Well, when you have a heart attack, you do not suddenly rush out first and get the phone book and say, `Who can I ring and what's the best deal I can get?' You cannot say, `I know my doctor will be there because he has been waiting for me to have a heart attack'. The same argument applies if I am in a car crash or any other emergency—and most health care arises from an emergency; the other planned care is different. But in the intervening period when the funds have run all of those ads—and they do not run them much today—what has happened in our regions is that the standard of public hospital care has vastly improved.

When I go into John Hunter Hospital, one of our top technology hospitals in the Hunter region which is servicing the area almost up to the Queensland border, I am aware that about 20 per cent of its patients come from outside the region because it is a centre of excellence. The wards are designed for four or six persons. It is a dignified, high quality hospital and with a high standard of care.

The health insurance funds cannot run the line now that it is a terrible situation to be placed into care in a public ward of a public hospital; what a disgraceful situation to be placed in. The quality of care is so much better. And they cannot really run that line now about not having a doctor of choice. You notice that that is not on there so much. Now they are running the other story saying, `We will go broke! Fewer than one in three persons in this country contributes to private health insurance.' Why? Because they are not fools; they realise they are not getting value. More people have been in the public hospital for treatment and care. I get this repeatedly in my electorate, I hear people on the radio, I see letters to the editor and I meet people at functions. They have such compliments to make about the standard of care, how good it was and how good the specialists were at John Hunter Hospital in Newcastle.

That is what is different. It has become tougher and tougher for the health insurance funds to sell that bag of goods that they have gotten away with for so long, with the result that more people leave and fewer people are left to pay the costs that have to be paid out in respect of health care. The solution is not to try and force people into private health insurance companies or funds; the solution is to further improve the public hospital system. But looking at these bills and looking at the budget overall, for this government and the Minister for Health (Dr Wooldridge) to be out there carrying on the way they do and criticising the system; lambasting people who have exercised their discretion in making a tough decision, with the income that they have available to them, to opt out of voluntary health insurance funds; criticising them when they realise that there is no value for them, I think it is odious and dishonest. They are pretending to aged people that they need to be in a private health insurance fund. No matter what their level of income is, to go on with that line is a total misrepresentation and an act of dishonesty.

As I conclude in these few seconds, Madam Deputy Speaker, let may say that that debate has yet to be run and we will do everything possible to ensure that this government does not dismantle Medicare as, I am sure, it is intent upon doing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take the opportunity today, particularly given that there are changes to funding for the arts, to outline what might be a stocktake of the Howard government's performance to date in the area of the arts.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is important to recognise that during the election campaign, the Liberal Party's arts policy statement was very clear. It was entitled For Art's Sake—A Fair Go and released by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in February of 1996. It clearly promised, and I quote:
The coalition will not only maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the arts, but it is committed to new spending initiatives.
In the press release that accompanied the Prime Minister's statement he pledged, and I quote again:
. . . to maintain the existing level of Commonwealth funding.
and, furthermore, he said:
. . . to provide $60 million over three years for initiatives which will provide greater public access to the arts and encourage young and emerging artists.
So, they will maintain the existing level and add a further $60 million—a very generous offer.

But by any measure, the Liberals have broken this core promise to the arts community—both elements of it. If you look at the 1996‐97 budget for the arts and culture through the Department of Communications and the Arts, excluding departmental running costs, which were also reduced I might say, that amounts to $393.4 million. This is down from $451.73 million, a reduction of 13 per cent or $58 million overall. So much for maintaining the level of funding.

If you take the additional coalition pledge of more—$60 million over three years factored in—then funding this financial year is $78 million short of the pre‐election undertakings. There have been a couple of changes—I might say they are arbitrary ones—to that budget but that, by and large, is the position today. That is without taking into account the undoubted impact on arts and culture of cuts to the ABC and to ATSIC, and the added pressure on running costs for performing arts organisations of imminent award improvements for entertainment industry employees which the minister knew were in the pipeline.

Overall, the coalition has broken a series of promises and abolished a number of arts initiatives of the former government—it appears simply because they were from the former government—and it has implemented some of its more modest arts promises, but their value falls well short of the cuts and broken promises that have been part of the last budget.

I just want to touch on a couple of these cuts before going into some detail on one of the meanest of them all and that is the cuts to public lending rights and education lending rights. The Liberals, when in opposition, promised to continue to recognise and support the Australia Council as a primary administrator of Commonwealth arts funding. But, regrettably, this recognition and support which, for the moment, does not even extend to getting a new chairperson for the Australia Council, did not extend to funding which has actually been cut by $16.4 million over four years. So, it is supported, but with a lot of the stays pulled out from underneath it.

This is despite Senator Alston's claim or challenge that, while on paper it might look as though the Australia Council is losing money, in fact it is not, as he said it was losing responsibility commensurate with the amount going elsewhere. For a while, the arts community swallowed that line, but they are now very clear about it, as they find that their allocations are actually having to be reduced by—surprise, surprise!—pretty much the amount indicated by that loss of base funding.

Take, for instance, the Major Organisations Board, which comes under the aegis of the Australia Council and provides triennial funding for 17 major arts companies. Again, the Liberals, when in opposition, claimed that a coalition government would at least maintain the existing level of financial support for the Major Organisations Board. But that board is now experiencing cuts of about $250,000 in this financial year, and this again clearly breaks the coalition's promise.

Similarly, the four state opera companies—now reduced to three, courtesy of Jeff Kennett in Victoria—were encouraged to join the Major Organisations Board, but not at the expense of existing funding arrangements. In the budget we have just seen, there are no additional funds for these companies to join the Major Organisations Board, and the government has clearly failed to deliver on the promise to the state opera companies in terms of funding, as well.

The coalition, when in opposition, also claimed to be strong supporters of the idea of triennial funding, and said that the coalition `has for many years been a supporter of triennial funding for major arts organisations', and that the coalition has `long recognised the need for greater security in arts funding to enable major organisations to plan with certainty.' I agree with both of those sentiments; but, in slashing the Australia Council's budget part way through the triennium—which is what has happened, taking $16.4 million out—the coalition has actually abandoned the key principle of benefit in triennial funding; that is, certainty. There is no certainty at all now.

The coalition also promised to examine the need to extend triennial funding to major arts education institutions, such as the National Institution of Dramatic Art, the Australian Ballet School and the Australian Film, Television and Radio School. That is not being delivered, either. Indeed, the Australian Film, Television and Radio School had its funding cut by nearly five per cent.

There have also been a number of cuts to our major national institutions, such as the National Museum of Australia. The government is still fiddling around with funding for a new museum. It has made a commitment, but that does not appear anywhere in either the previous budget documents or the revised estimates. We are yet to know where the $100 million is coming from or whether, indeed, it will be delivered.

There have been cuts to the National Gallery, the National Maritime Museum, the National Library, and the National Film and Sound Archive, which has particular reason for complaint. There was a plan to construct a new, purpose built facility for the National Film and Sound Archive, and those who have not been to have a look at the existing facility should do so, because they would be ashamed that the proposal budgeted for in 1995‐96 has actually been scrapped, despite considerable expenditure already on planning and design work.

The National Film and Sound Archive is not actually a safe place to work, let alone a safe place to store the very important material that it stocks. No allocation has been made for alternatives to the construction project, and the staff will have to continue to endure some very appalling working conditions. The Australian Archives also experienced reduction, as did the other agencies; but, in their case, the cuts have been compounded by fixed property expenses and the fact that the remainder of the budget is principally salaries, and so they have very little discretion.

BREAK.PARA: I want to talk briefly, too, about the film and television area because, as well as having cuts in the budget, we have had the Gonski review—which, once people had a good look at it, produced a considerable level of alarm in the film and television area. Again, we had a pledge being made by the then opposition and now government to maintain the existing level of Commonwealth funding for Australia's film industry and industry bodies—a very clear statement. But that promise, too, has been broken.

Film industry bodies, including the Australian Film, Television and Radio School, Film Australia, the Australian Film Commission and the Film Finance Corporation, received $90.2 million in 1995‐96, and that is excluding the commercial television production fund. Under this current budget, funding for the industry fell to $84 million, a cut of seven per cent. The specific cuts included 4.9 per cent from the Australian Film and Television School, three per cent from the Film Finance Corporation, three per cent from the commercial television production fund, and a whacking 20 per cent from the Australian Film Commission. Hardest hit under the Australian Film Commission was the special production fund to develop new projects. Cutting off the lifeblood of new work does not seem like a very smart way to treat the arts.

Gonski's review, while it reassured people to the extent that he said that there should be no further reductions in funding for film and television, had a series of recommendations which would again see that creative spark of the young film producer nipped in the bud because he recommended that screen culture funding be reduced from $3 million to $1 million and that those savings be transferred to a special production fund. Why this should be the case is anyone's guess. The argument in Gonski is very shoddy I would have to say and the cuts to screen culture funding will result in defunding the screen culture resource organisations like Open Channel, Metro Television, the Film and Television Institute in my own state, Brisbane Independent Filmmakers, the Media Resource Centre. These are all organisations that cultivate new workers in the field, whether they are scriptwriters, directors and so on.

It is very shortsighted if the government accepts that recommendation and I hope that they will not, especially given the cuts to the ABC and the recommendations by Mansfield that there be outsourcing of ABC drama and documentary work which will have a devastating effect on the development of new workers in the field—a role that the ABC often does thanklessly—its workers then being pinched (if I can use that term) by the commercial television producers.

I want to speak in the time left available to me about, as I said, one of the really miserable acts of this government. It cannot be justified on the grounds of the so-called black hole—this furphy that we have been asked to believe in—because no-one is actually clear how much money it really saves but the abolition of education lending rights and the windback of public lending rights, I think, deserves special condemnation.

I had the pleasure earlier this year of speaking during the Sydney Festival—the Sydney Writers Festival—and I can tell you the writers throughout Australia are up in arms about this measure. I want to begin by on this issue quoting former New South Wales Liberal Senator Peter Baume, someone I don't quote as a rule I would have to say. He once said in a parliamentary debate that `one of the marks of a civilised society is surely the extent to which it is involved in the arts and values its culture and cultural activity'. I would have to say that the Howard government's changes to the public lending rights scheme and its abandonment of education lending rights is indeed, as Senator Baume said, a very clear measure of the value it places on cultural activity—in other words, practically zero.

As I am sure most members know, public lending rights were introduced to compensate authors and publishers for income lost for the public benefit of their books being available on loan through public libraries. In other words, they recognised that it benefited the community but the authors were getting no recompense financially because their books were not being purchased. I am sure we all agree that it is necessary that Australians, no matter what their means, have access to books in this way—no-one is complaining about that. But it is also necessary to recognise that authors should be compensated, albeit modestly as the program did, for their loss of potential income. Compensation schemes of this kind were first introduced into Scandinavia in the 1940s. In the English speaking world the scheme was pioneered by New Zealand in 1973, followed by Australia under Whitlam in 1974 and the United Kingdom in 1979 and it has subsequently spread throughout much of the world. As I indicated, it was Gough Whitlam who implemented the public lending rights scheme in 1974 following recommendations by the Literature Board of the then Australia Council for the Arts. The board had undertaken a study of the concept at the direction of the new Prime Minister after he had received representations from a great many authors and publishers, and there was a very strong concerted campaign initiated by the Australian Society of Authors as far back as 1963, so it has a long and honourable history. In 1975 a bill was drafted to give the scheme a statutory base. The sacking of the Whitlam government and the dissolution of parliament saw the bill lapse but it did finally get into law when we got back into government in 1983, having limped along in the interregnum.

Susan Ryan announced at Sydney's Nimrod Theatre that Labor would introduce legislation to entrench public lending rights—something that was actually achieved in 1985—and at the time the coalition actually supported it. Interestingly, one of the coalition's reservations about the bill was that it gave the minister power to alter the scheme, including payment rates, by way of a notice in the government gazette and without the opportunity for parliamentary review. In fact, David Connolly told parliament at that time that the provision raised the prospect of steps by any future minister of any future government effectively to emasculate this program without going anywhere near parliament—something the minister has just done! He was very prescient, indeed, because Senator Alston used that device to change the scheme without consulting authors, without consulting the public lending rights advisory committee or the parliament—unilateral action.

We had further announced in 1994 in Creative Nation that we would extend the public lending rights scheme to education libraries and actually set aside $750,000 for that purpose for this last financial year which was to be its first year of operation. That was also cut.

The changes to public lending rights are particularly miserable. Authors were informed about the changes to the public lending rights scheme in a most unsatisfactory way. They were told more than a week after the budget was brought down at a time of much trumpeting by the minister about the government's allocation for the arts. He was saying how wonderfully they had done yet, meanwhile, he slipped this very nasty decision through in a bureaucratic letter. There was no announcement by the minister of the changes, just a four-paragraph, highly political and fatuous letter from a bureaucrat who said, amongst other things, and with masterful understatement, that `tight fiscal constraints' necessitated `changes' to education lending rights. That is the most interesting way of saying that the scheme had been killed stone dead! There was nothing left of it. `Changes' is right.

The letter also said that the changes to public lending rights were to `update and streamline its operation' and to `maintain the integrity of public lending rights'. The authors around Australia were really angry at the tone of the letter and the fact that it did not come from the minister. I guess they felt a great sense of relief to be reassured that it was something to `maintain the integrity' and `update and streamline' the scheme when what it looked like was a very ill-conceived and poorly executed cost cutting measure.

As you know—I hope members know—there were payments available across the board no matter how much you got from the public lending rights scheme. What the minister did was to cease payments of less than $50 per book because, in Senator Alston's words during the estimates committee debate on this, `the administrative costs might outweigh the benefit'.

I am sure the recipients do not share that view. They are often on very low incomes, indeed. Fifty dollars is $50; $45 is $45. While the minister's office sought to suggest that only a handful of people would be affected by the changes, when we questioned him in estimates it was made very clear that some 646 payments in the last year were for less than $50. Interestingly, even if that is an inefficient way of making payments—small cheque by small cheque—the government, at the same time, also ruled out accumulating amounts of less than $50 over more than one financial year to the point where it is cost effective to process the cheque. So the argument about cost effectiveness has to be seen as purely disingenuous.

It is also pretty hard to see any rationale, other than the ideologically driven cost cutting, for the decision to scrap payments for books which have been out of print for more than 25 years. In other words, if you are an author who happens to have written a book 25 years ago and it is still being borrowed—in other words, it is popular, well read and well regarded—suddenly you do not get any more from the scheme. As the Australian Society of Authors points out, this is like a punishment for success. It is particularly harsh on the older writers for whom this is the closest thing to superannuation that they have. They may well have stopped writing. They may not be producing more material.

The final element was the scrapping of payments to estates, to descendants and spouses of deceased authors. That is clearly unjust, particularly in the case of a spouse where this may be the only source of superannuation or income that they have from the person who is now deceased.

It so incensed the writers of Australia that they had a special discussion of this during the Sydney Writers' Festival and in their press release they said very clearly what they thought of it. It is headed, `You can't eat an Order of Australia'. In other words, a lot of these authors are so well regarded that they have gongs of various descriptions but no money from the government to go with it. They issued this declaration—the lending right declaration. It says:

With the introduction of public lending rights in 1975 the Australian government recognised the right of book creators to be recompensed for the use of their books in the public library system. This recognition was extended in 1994 to cover educational libraries through the Educational Lending Rights Scheme. Over recent months, lending rights have been seriously jeopardised. In the 1996 budget, the federal government stopped the Educational Lending Rights Scheme before any payments were made. At the same time, changes to the Public Lending Rights Scheme reduced the number of eligible books and the number of eligible creators. These changes undermined the very nature of the Public Lending Rights Scheme. We, the undersigned, affirm that lending right is not a grant or a form of literary alms giving, it is a legitimate entitlement that should not be taken away.
As an aside, I indicate that I very strongly endorse that point of view. They went on to say:
We call upon the Australian government to reinstate both the Educational Lending Rights Scheme and those areas of the Public Lending Rights Scheme which have recently been cut.

The signatories will interest members: Patsy Adam-Smith, AO, OBE; Allan Ashbolt; Nancy Cato, AM; Jon Cleary; Dorothy Hewett, AM; Robert Ingpen; Elizabeth Jolley; Merv Lilley; Barry Oakley; Eric Rolls, AM; Tom Shapcott, AO; Eleanor Spence; Jessica Anderson; Thea Astley; Don Charlwood, AM; Geoffrey Dutton, AO; Donald Horne, AO; Barbara Jefferis, AM; Tom Keneally, AO; Christobel Mattingley; Ruth Park, AM; Vincent Serventy, AM; Ivan Southall, AM; Morris West, AM; and Judith Wright McKinney.

Those writers were chosen because they are all writers affected by the 25‐year rule. They are all writers still being read and borrowed from our public libraries. They are all writers mortally offended, and rightly so, by the actions of the arts minister and this government. These writers, I think, are quite within their rights to now regard the government as one whose word cannot be trusted and which has, in former Senator Baume's words, no interest in the arts or in the value of the arts to our culture. Otherwise, why would you treat these authors in this way?

The scheme itself is very modest, even at the stage that these cuts were made. From recollection, you are only talking about $4.5 to $5 million, and the minister was not even able to tell the Senate estimates committee what savings would result from these measures that he had introduced.

If you look at the approach that the minister and the government have taken to the whole area of the arts, I think it is very clear indeed that they have no regard for these things, whether it is through the Australia Council, the public lending rights cuts, the cuts to films, the cuts to the ABC and further cuts contemplated in the ABC's television production.

I said to the Sydney writers when I spoke to them in January that they would be asked to believe in the 1996 B‐grade movie The Black Hole is Going to Get You as a justification for these cuts. And they have been. As I say, there is no such justification in this case and indeed not in others either. This black hole has been proffered as the reason for many of the coalition budget cuts, including those to education and public lending rights, but it has been pretty selective. This black hole has been pretty selective in its consumption patterns. It consumed the ABC, it consumed ATSIC and it consumed the Australia Council. It consumed Australian authors, but it did not consume the defence budget or the diesel fuel rebate, and it did not consume Tasmania's Axemen's Hall of Fame. It also has not consumed the AFL Hall of Fame, which has been given a million dollars recently. So it is a very selective black hole, and I think the authors of Australia have every right to be mortally offended by the attitude of this government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Andrew) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAW AND JUSTICE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 December 1996, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is an omnibus bill which makes a number of uncontroversial amendments to various pieces of legislation. The acts affected are set out in the explanatory memorandum that has been circulated with the bill.
