The amendments really are of a minor policy nature to legislation primarily within the Attorney‐General's portfolio and related amendments to other legislation, and there are corrections to minor drafting errors and repeal of some spent provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition supports the bill before the House. I do not propose to take a long time in outlining a few of the amendments that are being put before the House, but I do want to say that amendments have been circulated, to be moved on behalf of the government, and I can indicate that, whilst we will not be opposing the amendments to be moved on behalf of the government, we will be giving consideration to referring those matters to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Committee for further consideration. Those amendments relate to allowing judges to make rules and to refer matters to judicial registrars for hearing. The initial concern is about the scope of the matters that could be referred and that the courts should not be forced to refer matters to judicial registrars because of resource limitations.

The other matter relates to compulsory mediation. It is the opposition's view that that must not be used in cases of power imbalance between the parties, but we trust that the court would apply its discretion appropriately. I just repeat: the shadow Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice, Senator Bolkus, may explore those matters further in the Senate.

Currently, the bill before us amends the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act 1975 to establish a small taxation claims tribunal and to provide for the reconstitution of the tribunal. It amends the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. It amends the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981. It amends the Crimes Act 1914 to correct an incorrect cross‐reference. There is an amendment to the Death Penalty Abolition Act 1973 to repeal a spent provision.

There is an amendment to the Evidence Act 1995 to clarify the admissibility of evidence that relates only to the credibility of a person whose prior statement has been admitted under a hearsay exception and who has not been called to give evidence. It also gives effect to certificates in relation to self‐incriminating evidence under the New South Wales Evidence Act in proceedings in federal and ACT courts and in prosecutions for Commonwealth and ACT offences. It also makes other amendments, including amendments to correct minor errors in the act and, it notes, to achieve consistency in drafting expression with the New South Wales Evidence Act, and includes further explanatory notes.

The omnibus bill also amends the Family Law Act 1975 and the Federal Court of Australia Act 1976, as well as the Judiciary Act 1903 to provide the Federal Court with jurisdiction under sections 75 and 76 of the constitution. There are amendments to the Foreign Judgments Act 1991, the Judges' Pensions Act 1968, and the Jurisdiction of Courts (Cross‐vesting) Act 1987. There are amendments to the Privacy Act 1988, the Service and Execution of Process Act 1992, the Superannuation Act 1976 and the Taxation Administration Act 1953.

We believe they are all non‐controversial amendments. It is appropriate—and it was also a practice of the former government—to bring them in in terms of an omnibus bill. This is a process which shows that there is an evolution over time with some of these acts. Some of them arise out of particular experiences in courts that are occurring throughout the country and which require a further requirement of legislation. They are non‐controversial, the opposition supports them and we do not believe there is anything that is sinister in any of these amendments.
On the Evidence Act, the explanatory memorandum says:

New section 108A restores the generally understood meaning of section 107, namely that evidence relevant only to the credibility of such a person is admissible only to the extent that he or she could have been cross‐examined on a matter relevant only to credit if he or she had given evidence as a witness. It achieves this result by providing that evidence relevant to his or her credibility is not admissible unless it has substantial probative value.

These amendments are not being driven by the government, they are not party‐political driven, they are driven by conscientious bureaucrats within the various public service departments who are continually monitoring legislation, continually monitoring court cases, and continually on the lookout to improve the legislation that governs Australians.

Too often, the bureaucrats within the various departments do not receive the credit they deserve. Before I came into parliament, after a short stint in private practice as a private solicitor, I went to work with the Legal Aid Commission of New South Wales, and after that I was a public defender and a legal aid barrister.

I had a commitment to public service and I was surrounded by a raft of people who had a genuine commitment to public service and who were providing professional advice to people charged with serious criminal offences. Too often I think we do not give full recognition to the professionalism of the support structure that we as a parliament receive. If we as politicians in many instances were half as good as those who serve us then we would have a better parliament all around—and that applies to both sides of the House. But I do have a commitment to public service. I believe that there are professional public servants throughout the system who are serving us well, and this is another classic example: we sometimes get up here to speak and the reality is that if it were not for the advice that we are given we would not know what we are talking about. And that advice is delivered in a professional, non‐partisan way.

So I applaud omnibus legislation like this that is continually improving the legislation that is on the statute books. That is not to say that there are not instances, frankly, where those in the Public Service could do with a little bit of on‐the‐ground experience, because it is one thing to be operating solely within the Public Service but there needs to be an interaction with practitioners on the ground. I commend the bill to the House and say that it does have the support of the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Madam Deputy Chair, may I have your indulgence to hand up the copy of the supplementary explanatory memorandum. Yesterday I directed that certain amendments which the government proposes to move at the in detail stage be circulated in the House, and I simply want to take the opportunity of presenting the supplementary memorandum at this stage in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Law and Justice Legislation Amendment Bill is a real mouthful and as a new member I am interested to hear the reference to it being omnibus legislation. That is a nice, neat, succinct way of describing it.

SPEECH.PARA: Just as an aside, I checked a dictionary meaning of `law'. It describes the meaning of that word as `a rule of conduct or action prescribed by the supreme governing authority and enforced by a sanction as an edict, decree, order, ordinance, statute or judicial decision.' Of course, the concept of law has spawned a whole array of subcategories: statute law, common law, civil law, canon law, natural law and so on.

When I was a student at university studying law I had to do jurisprudence, which is the theory of law. I learnt as a result of that course that the prevailing law was supposed to be a reflection of the morals of society. But in the ensuing years I found that jurisprudential theory was just that—theory—and that law is often the result of influences that have little to do with morals.

For the lawyer, `justice' is often partnered, or interchangeable, with the word `equity', but means variously `rightfulness, just dealing of men with each other and women with each other—and interchangeably, I guess—the principle of rectitude, of integrity.' It is also one of the cardinal virtues. The great radical English judge Lord Denning once said, `I would rather search for justice than search for certainty.' Throughout history there has certainly been a divergence of views about that quest on the part of judges. Some judges, the late Sir Owen Dixon being one of them, have been very much black‐letter judges and Lord Denning was of the other variety, but all have been contributing magnificently to our common law and to our jurisprudence.

The interconnection of the words `law' and `justice' is an aside I mention just to show that the bill does not really have the highfalutin meaning that is given to it, but rather it is directing a practical look at about 16 acts which are said to be in need of amendment. I do not demur from the proposition that they are rightfully being amended in accordance with trends both in the judicial system and the needs and aspirations of society generally.

I am only going to deal with a few of the particular acts in question. Initially I will look at the amendment to the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995. Advances in technology have brought click‐on access to a range of viewing options in some films accessed in the home and classification is consequently very difficult. The amendment will place the onus on the applicant to inform the Classification Board of the presence of any aberrant material. The penalty for failure to declare contentious material prior to classification will be automatic de-classification, providing the offending material would have resulted in the film being allocated a different classification.

The bill will also amend the criterion under which the Classification Board must refuse to approve an advertisement for a publication, film or computer game on the grounds that it contains child pornography with the amended criterion in the National Classification Code.

The Administrative Appeals Act 1975 is being amended to establish a small taxation claims tribunal, the purpose of which will be to provide taxpayers who have a tax dispute involving less than $5,000 with the option of a cheaper and more informal mechanism for the resolution of disputes with the ATO. The amount of $5,000 being set by regulation can be varied in the future when it is appropriate to do so, and many bills have that discretion in them as time passes.

It will be a cheaper, more informal and more accessible means of resolving disputes between the commissioner and the ordinary taxpayer and, in my view, it will be a very welcome reform. I am very much in favour of bringing justice as close as possible to the community, particularly in these areas. While the claims are frequently quite small, the anxiousness that they provoke amongst individuals in society is frequently out of all proportion to the size of the claim.

Indeed, it is interesting that in my practice as a lawyer, I have noticed that some of the worst cases involved the lowest amounts of money. Many people often get angry over very small amounts of money. This is a means of assisting the resolution of disputes, along with alternative dispute resolution. The latter form of mediation will be an integral part of the process, and that is very much to be applauded. I think it is a useful tool, although I must admit I was initially sceptical of some of the benefits of ADR. I think it has become a useful tool with the passing of time and is certainly not a fad; it is something that is here to stay.

The new tribunal will be under the umbrella of the AAT and, consequently, all of the powers of the AAT and the taxation appeals division will be exercisable by the tribunal. A non-refundable filing fee of $50 will be payable. Those fees have my support. The legislation even gives power to waive those fees in cases of hardship, which I think is commendable.

Overall, I do support the establishment of this tribunal. The name is a little odd. I find it does not run trippingly off the tongue and the juxtaposition of the words is a little odd. Perhaps the `taxation small claims tribunal' or the `small claims taxation tribunal' might have been a better way to word it, but that is just a personal view.

As far as the Family Law Act 1975 is concerned, the bill to amend that act will make a number of drafting and technical amendments which are the consequence of amendments made by the Family Law Reform Act 1995. The amendments will facilitate parents entering into enforceable agreements in relation to all aspects of parental responsibility, including child support, in the one document. Previously, parties contracting out of the Child Support (Assessment) Act had to enter into a child support agreement which could then be registered with the Child Support Agency. If they wanted to deal with parenting issues, they could also enter into a separate agreement, known as a parenting plan, which they could register with the Family Court. The effect of the bill will be to reduce the costs of parties to a marriage breakdown. Instead of a child support agreement and a parenting plan, a single document incorporating the provisions of both will now be capable of registration in both the Family Court and the Child Support Agency.

A further cost saving measure will be brought into effect by the bill. Courts of summary jurisdiction will be able to hear defended child maintenance applications—so‐called stage 1 matters—without the consent of both parties. This represents a reversion to the situation which existed prior to the enactment of the Family Law Reform Act 1995. This is a very good measure. But, if I may say so with the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) present, over a period of time it is going to become even more important for the courts of summary jurisdiction to look carefully at child support matters and to be able to make determinations.

At present, we have a review process under the Child Support (Assessment) Act which is totally and utterly unsatisfactory, where unsworn evidence is presented. Frequently in the course of my dealings since I have been a member, I have seen fraudulent documents put up to these review processes. The reviewing officer does not have the power to make determinations about those particular documents or the evidence that is presented, and is determining the matters at the review on the basis of material like that. It is totally unsatisfactory. In my view, it is about time we looked at the courts of summary jurisdiction, perhaps establishing a child support tribunal in the future that will be able to determine these things very cheaply, but on oath, so that we do not get these particular situations arising and both parties going away very unhappy and unsatisfied people. At least if they have their day in a cheap court, similar to the Small Claims Tribunal, they will be happier.

Overall, I applaud the movement to courts of summary jurisdiction in relation to defended child maintenance applications at the stage 1 stage. I can think of a case in my own electorate where, as a result of this bill, a particular party who was denied jurisdiction—denied access to the courts—will be able to come back and seek out a recalcitrant non‐payer. I support these measures, I applaud the trend in the bill and I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the members for Banks (Mr Melham) and Dickson (Mr Tony Smith), who seem to be regulars as far as Attorney‐General portfolio legislation debates are concerned. I thank the member for Banks in particular for support from the opposition, although I note it is somewhat qualified. I have previously commented to the member for Banks in debates—again, in the Main Committee—that it is not terribly satisfactory from the government point of view for questions to be raised in relation to legislation, but the legislation to be supported in order that the questions can be asked again in the Senate where I am not there to answer them. In this case, we do not really have the questions in more than mere outline. However, being grateful for small mercies, we are grateful for the opposition's support at this stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Banks mentioned the judicial registrars in the Federal Court and raised the issue of whether there should be any necessity for jurisdiction in matters involving up to $100,000 to be referred to them. I have not discussed this with the Chief Justice of the Federal Court, nor sought particular advice on it.

My understanding of the way it would work in the Federal Court is that a case would be started in the Federal Court. They have introduced a new system which they refer to as the docket system under which the case will be assigned to a judge. The judge will have sole responsibility for that case except that when this legislation is through the judge will be able to refer a case within the relevant limits to a judicial registrar to be dealing with. On that basis there is no sort of compulsory conferring of jurisdiction at the expense of judges on judicial registrars; it will still be under the control of the judges.

In relation to mediation he raised not surprisingly the question of why, given the consensual nature of mediation, it should be seen to be the subject of coercion, the subject of an order. I think if you put it into context it is not quite so bad. Often mediation can be seen to be a process that involves consensus in participation and consensus in outcome but there is, so long as there is consensus in outcome, no reason why people should not be compelled to at least sit around the table.

In the Federal Court we are mainly dealing with cases of a commercial nature and cases where often the parties will have equal bargaining power. On that basis I think the court would soon be able to determine whether a case is appropriate for an order for mediation and the parties would in any event, the mediation process being consensual in nature, control both the process and the outcome.

The question has been raised in the past. The Law Council of Australia in a submission some three years ago in relation to court annex mediation suggested the inclusion of a power for a judge to be able to refer matters to mediation without the consent of the parties. The Law Council view was that although the traditional model promotes mediation as a voluntary process, experience in jurisdictions where mediations can be compulsory suggests that satisfactory outcomes can be achieved, notwithstanding that parties have been directed to mediation.

I have sought the views of the National Alternative Dispute Resolution Advisory Council, NADRAC, specifically on the proposed amendment. The Council advised that mandatory referral to mediation is acceptable in some circumstances despite the parties' initial unwillingness to participate in the process. In some cases the unwillingness of the parties to mediate is not necessarily a good indicator of their capacity to be helped by the process. For example, they may believe that they cannot resolve the dispute themselves but NADRAC's view is that with the assistance of a skilled mediator they may be able to achieve a resolution despite their initial misgivings. In this particular area the Chief Justice of the Federal Court has advised me that the court does not anticipate forcing unwilling parties to continue in mediation if the initial reference was unproductive.

The member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) raised some jurisprudential issues at the outset which I will save for another day. He then referred specifically to the small taxation claims tribunal and questioned the appropriateness of the name in particular. I think like most organs of government it will quickly acquire a nickname or an acronym and whether it is called the small taxation claims tribunal, the small claims in taxation tribunal or some other variant will not really matter much. Everyone will know what we are talking about. The name is, in fact despite its length and clumsiness in speech, an accurate description of its function.

The member for Dickson also mentioned child support and welcomed a move towards the involvement of courts of summary jurisdiction in the assessment of child support. The child support agency is in fact an agency for which the assistant treasurer is responsible. The review to which the member referred that takes place within the child support agency of an assessment is not the subject of this bill and is not the subject of legislation for which my portfolio has responsibility and therefore that also can be reserved for another day.

In the circumstances, all the other parts of the bill appear to have the support of both sides of the House and I will cease further comment. I simply commend the bill to the House and, as indicated, I anticipate that there will be government amendments moved in the consideration of detail stage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 1 to 5:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 2, page 2 (after line 4), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) Items 1A to 1D of Schedule 8 commence immediately after the commencement of item 19 of Schedule 16 to the Workplace Relations and Other Legislation Amendment Act 1996 .

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 8, page 19 (after line 3), before item 1, insert:

PARA.TAB: Insert:

(1A) The Rules of Court may delegate to the Judicial Registrars, either generally or as otherwise provided in the Rules, all or any of the Court's powers in relation to proceedings in the Court in the exercise of the Court's original jurisdiction, except:

TAB.TAB: (a) proceedings in which the amount sought, or the value of the subject matter, is more than $100,000; and
(b) proceedings for a prerogative writ or an order in the nature of a prerogative writ; and
(c) proceedings that involve a claim under the Workplace Relations Act 1996 ; and
(d) proceedings arising under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act 1986 ; and
(e) proceedings arising under the Native Title Act 1993 .

PARA.TAB: Powers of the Court in relation to proceedings mentioned in any of paragraphs (a) to (e) may, however, be delegated to Judicial Registrars by the Rules of Court if this is expressly provided for by another provision of this or any other Act.
Omit "Without limiting subsection (1), Rules of Court made in respect of that subsection", substitute "Rules of Court made for the purposes of this section".
Omit "subsection (1)", substitute "this section".
Omit "subsection (1)", substitute "this section".

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 8, page 19 (line 10), omit "(1A)", substitute "(1AA)".
(4) Schedule 8, page 19 (after line 14), after item 2, insert:

PARA.TAB: Omit "On or after", substitute "Subject to subsection (2A), on or after".
Insert:

(2A) An appeal may not be brought to the High Court from a judgment of the Supreme Court of the Australian Capital Territory given after the commencement of this subsection when that Court is known as the Court of Disputed Elections under subsection 252(1) of the Electoral Act 1992 of that Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 8, page 21 (after line 10), at the end of the Schedule, add:

PARA.TAB: Omit ", with the consent of the parties to proceedings in the Court, by order refer the proceedings", substitute "by order refer the proceedings in the Court".
Insert:

(1A) Referrals under subsection (1) to a mediator may be made with or without the consent of the parties to the proceedings. However, referrals to an arbitrator may be made only with the consent of the parties.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, I think the issues arising out of the amendments have been dealt with in the debate. In fact, they comprised the principal subject of the debate. On that basis I have nothing further to say.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill has been agreed to with an amendment. The question now is that the bill be reported to the House with an amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr McGauran:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports this legislation. It puts into place the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Agreement signed by the New Zealand government and the COAG ministers in mid‐1996 and it follows a process which was begun by the Labor government back in 1992. It has the effect of providing for mutual recognition of regulatory standards and occupations in both Australia and New Zealand, and it enables enactment of legislation applying uniformly throughout Australia so that two important areas are picked up.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, goods can be sold between Australia and New Zealand without restrictions caused by differences in product standards and other regulatory requirements and, secondly, persons registered to practise in a mutually recognised occupation are given mobility between the two countries without the need to undergo further testing or examination.

The bill does contain a number of exclusions and exemptions. They go to medical practitioners, to quarantine, to endangered species, to firearms, censorship and certain chemicals. As I say, this gives effect to a process which Labor put in place. We are pleased that it has come to fruition and the opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone, Sharman, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to support the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill 1996. It is a bill all about facilitating free trade by harmonising the regulatory standards that apply to the exchange of goods and workers between Australia and New Zealand.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is an extension of the Mutual Recognition Act 1992 which enabled the free movement of goods and the recognition of occupations across state and territory borders in Australia. This means that, with specific exceptions, states and territories, and now also New Zealand, recognise each other's regulatory standards with respect to both goods and occupations.

This bill implements the trans‐Tasman mutual recognition arrangement which was signed by the Prime Minister, Mr John Howard, premiers and chief ministers at the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments held on 14 June 1996. The arrangement was then signed by the Prime Minister of New Zealand in July 1996.

This bill recognises that the trans‐Tasman mutual recognition arrangement was finalised after the release of a discussion paper in April 1995 by the Council of Australian Governments and the government of New Zealand. Like all good legislation, it sought and took into account very extensive feedback, in the form of industry views and the views of different professional organisations representing their workers. This bill therefore represents a great deal of cooperative and commonsense outcomes and, as you have already heard, it is supported by both sides of the House.

Australia enjoys an extremely close relationship with New Zealand. For our producers and manufacturers, New Zealand is geographically and culturally close. We have no language barriers and we share a common British colonial heritage which means that our food, our clothing and much of our technology is in common. It can cost less to transfer goods, and indeed even people, between Australia and New Zealand than it costs to transport the same product and people from one side of Australia to the other. The New Zealand market is generally not oversupplied with new products and there are opportunities arising in most segments for Australia and vice versa. This is a bill which is of mutual economic advantage to New Zealand.

BREAK.PARA: New Zealand has a population of 3.64 million, which provides it with a market in Australia roughly six times that of its own domestic market. It is our third largest trading partner and this trans‐Tasman food trade is now worth more than $1 billion annually. In 1994, Australia was New Zealand's largest export destination. However, Australia was New Zealand's major import source and it has been increasing this lead from its nearest competitor, the European Union, over the last five years.

This trans‐Tasman mutual recognition bill builds on the cooperative and mutually beneficial economic and trade framework which was developed under the Australia‐New Zealand Closer Economic Relations trade agreement. It is a logical extension of that agreement and we expect that the outcomes of this bill will provide a model of cooperation and free trade that others can look at and perhaps emulate throughout the region and then, perhaps, throughout the rest of the world. The Closer Economic Relations trade agreement between Australia and New Zealand has already eliminated tariff barriers to trade between the two countries and it has led to the creation of the Australia New Zealand Food Authority.

This bill will specifically allow a person registered to practise an occupation, a profession or a trade in Australia to seek automatic registration to practise the equivalent occupation in New Zealand, or vice versa. An Australian or a New Zealander will simply need to give notice to the relevant registration authority, as well as evidence of their home registration in their own jurisdiction, to be entitled to commence work in an equivalent occupation in the new place. This process should be quite quick and simple. If the activities carried out by practitioners registered in their own jurisdiction are not substantially the same in the other country, a registration authority will impose conditions upon the person's registration in order to achieve some equivalence.

Medical practitioners are specifically exempt from the operation of this legislation. This is in recognition of the fact that vocational registration in Australia has federal government financial implications through practitioner reimbursement through the Medicare system. The exemption of medical practitioners under this act will not affect existing arrangements relating to the registration rights of New Zealanders and Australian medical practitioners. Under these existing arrangements doctors who are graduates of New Zealand or Australian medical schools are accredited by the Australian Medical Council and they are able to seek registration in any Australian jurisdiction and in New Zealand.

Medical practitioners registered in New Zealand but trained in a third country will also continue to be required to sit and pass the Australian Medical Council exams for overseas trained doctors before they can be registered in an Australian jurisdiction. And the reverse applies. Australian registered but third country trained medical practitioners will continue to be required to pass the exams of the Medical Council of New Zealand.

With regard to the sale of goods under the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill, a good that can be legally sold in an Australian jurisdiction will also be able to be sold in New Zealand, and vice versa. This is as long as the goods meet the regulatory requirements for their sale in their home jurisdiction, in other words, where they were manufactured or first imported. This means that producers in Australia will only have to ensure that their products comply with the laws for their sale in Australia. They will then be free to distribute and sell their products in New Zealand without any further testing or assessments—a great saving in costs and time.

However, there are exclusions to mutual recognition which will safeguard communities on both sides of the Tasman. Laws not covered by the arrangements include customs controls on prohibited goods, tariff measures and anti‐dumping, intellectual property, non‐discriminatory taxation and business franchise laws, and relevant international obligations such as wildlife protection and hazard waste disposal issues. Exemptions will cover quarantine laws, laws on endangered species, laws on firearms and indecent material, agricultural and veterinary chemicals, fireworks and gaming machines.

The banning of products subject to quarantine restrictions exported between Australia and New Zealand is an obvious example of one of the exemption categories in the bill. Australia currently bans the importation of fresh pome fruit such as apples and pears from New Zealand, for example. This is because of the risk of importing the deadly pome fruit disease, apple and pear fire blight. While New Zealand orchards are infected with the fire blight, Australia has so far remained fire blight free. The current quarantine bans which stop the importation of fresh New Zealand apples and pears into this country will remain as long as that quarantine ban remains in place, but there is no restriction on processed apple or pear exported from New Zealand. There the mutuality is complete.

Special exemption would also apply to a number of areas of health and safety regulations where it was considered that mutual recognition would not be appropriate. In these areas the arrangement establishes so‐called cooperative programs whereby Australia and New Zealand will develop harmonised standards. Special exemptions will apply to therapeutic goods, electromagnetic compatibility standards and radiocommunications equipment, motor vehicles, gas appliances, hazardous substances, industrial chemicals and dangerous goods.

This bill opens up opportunities for greater export opportunity for so many sectors in Australia. For example, confectionery and dairy manufacturing should stand to gain substantially. Mutual recognition will permit the sale of Australian low fat ice‐creams and those containing artificial sweeteners in New Zealand. New Zealand currently has different standards of food solid levels and sweeteners in such products. In Australia the low fat, low energy ice‐creams, desserts and so on are some of the fastest growing sectors in our markets, and one would expect a similar growth in market share when consumers in New Zealand can also purchase such products, initially from Australia but also when their own domestic production of these products grows. Thus the harmonisation of food standards between Australia and New Zealand opens up greater opportunities for New Zealanders, who will also have access to larger markets, and for Australians, who will have access to market share growth.

In terms of product safety, where the New Zealand and Australian product safety standards are different these standards will initially be made subject to a temporary exemption. This act provides a mechanism for the temporary exemption of a good or a law relating to a good from the operation of the scheme for a period of 12 months. During this time the relevant ministerial council would determine whether a standard should apply to the goods and, if so, what standard. The Ministerial Council on Consumer Affairs will then work towards developing appropriate harmonisation arrangements. If no agreement can be reached on product standards for safety, the product or class of goods can be exempted permanently from the operation of the act.

As already noted, the scheme does not affect laws relating to quarantine, firearms, endangered species and other prohibited imports, nor will the scheme affect Australia's or New Zealand's intellectual property laws, taxation laws or tariff regimes. So it is a win‐win circumstance all round.

In terms of labelling—another area of considerable concern to both countries as they exchange their goods and services—the trans‐Tasman mutual recognition arrangement will reduce costs but will not reduce in any way the current protection in relation to false or misleading labelling. The Commonwealth Trade Practices Act 1974 and the New Zealand Fair Trading Act 1986 both prohibit the sale of goods that make a false or misleading representation concerning the origin of the goods.

Under the trans‐Tasman mutual recognition arrangement, goods must be classified as legally able to be sold in New Zealand, for example, before they can be sold in the other country—in this case, Australia. A good falsely claiming New Zealand origin would be in breach of the New Zealand Fair Trading Act and hence could not be legally sold in New Zealand. In these circumstances, mutual recognition would simply not apply.

In 1995, legislation was passed forming the Australia New Zealand Food Authority. This allowed for a joint food standards setting system for Australia and New Zealand and also provided for the harmonisation of food standards and consumer information on the ingredients for food between the two countries. Thus we have long cooperated in these matters and will continue to reap the mutual benefits.

The bill should eliminate much of the costs associated with the different requirements in the labelling of such things as poisons, chemicals, solvent or resin labelling requirements. The Food Industry Council of Australia has said that there are substantial economic benefits arising from doing away with the need to relabel Australian goods before they can be exported to, and sold in, New Zealand. The Food Industry Council argues that the New Zealand market is very important to the Australian food industry, and the harmonisation now possible under this bill will substantially assist New Zealand and Australia to better compete in third markets.

The country of origin labelling laws in both Australia and New Zealand adhere to WTO rules which, in respect of food, require the countries to have in place requirements that are consistent with the international Codex standard. This is made under the auspices of the Food and Agriculture Organisation. While both countries have WTO consistent arrangements in place, country of origin labelling requirements for food products are to be harmonised by the recently established Australian and New Zealand Food Authority. Thus we will also be consistent with our international obligations under this new arrangement.

In conclusion, the government is committed to reviewing the way it regulates Australian industry, to reduce delays and impediments to competition and to enhance commercial prospects for industry. We want to minimise costs and maximise opportunities for our industry to compete and succeed in overseas markets. At the same time, we are determined to maintain a high standard of consumer protection. The bill offers all of those advantages and, as I said before, is a model for what can be achieved both in our region and beyond, in the Northern Hemisphere.

The scheme reflects the high degree of confidence which exists between Australia and New Zealand in respect of each other's regulations, regulatory systems and decision making processes. It will help to remove regulatory barriers to the movement of goods and services providers across the Tasman. It will enhance our international competitiveness and reduce compliance costs. Therefore, I very strongly support the bill before the House and recommend its swift passage through the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Andrew, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDREW THOMSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I convey Minister Downer's regrets at not being able to attend to sum up the debate on the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill 1996. Happily, it is a debate that has been free of a lot of contention—as I understand the previous bill has been, from the words the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) offered in his summing up.

SPEECH.PARA: Briefly, the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) indicated the opposition's support for the bill. He noted exemptions made to the scheme, such as those for medical practitioners, quarantine, endangered species, firearms, dangerous goods and certain other categories, such that those who might have some concerns about a new stage in the free flow of goods and services in the practice of occupations between Australia and New Zealand should have their concerns laid at rest.

The member for Murray (Mrs Stone) began by describing the bill and the scheme within it as one that is both cooperative and of great commonsense. She raised a few concerns about labelling and country of origin but noted, with some satisfaction I think, that the protections available under both New Zealand's Fair Trading Act and Australia's Trade Practices Act remain in place within this scheme.

That said, it is obvious that the Trans‐Tasman Mutual Recognition Bill will produce a number of significant benefits for both sides in the agreement. These benefits include a greater choice for consumers, reduced compliance costs for manufacturers, and greater cooperation between the regulatory authorities on both sides. Our two economies are already closely integrated, with extensive trade and a largely unrestricted flow of people, so this sort of agreement should suit that reality very well.

I note that a new acronym is going to enter the Australian political lexicon—I would have thought we had enough already. TTMRA—I am not sure exactly how that will be pronounced by people within officialdom who have something to do with it, but it may be `titmra' or something like that—represents a natural extension of our existing close ties with New Zealand.

I have said in the past that there are few things more unpleasant within this place than the old salad bar in the members' dining room and debating tax bills. With the salad bar having been changed to something much better, and with fewer tax bills before us, some of the better things within this place now are debating bills and resolutions that pertain to our relations with our cousins in New Zealand and anything to do with free trade. Both those things bring a warm glow to my heart.

It is worth adding that, in population terms, this scheme will increase the coverage of existing Australian mutual recognition agreements by about 20 per cent. The market of both countries combined will be over 21 million people. This will be very important, not only for the people within both markets, but for our Pacific neighbours—island states such as Vanuatu, Fiji and Kiribati.

Some gentlemen from Kiribati happened to visit me this afternoon. They told me, among other things, that the islands in the Kiribati archipelago stretch the equivalent distance from Perth to Sydney and yet the total landmass is only one‐third of the ACT. Countries like that that have great difficulties sustaining themselves as an economy can only do better as trans‐Tasman trade between Australia and New Zealand flourishes. So more people will benefit from this scheme than first meets the eye.

BREAK.PARA: I thank the opposition for its cooperation. I gather from the remarks of the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean) that, in a previous guise, the opposition had a great deal to do with drafting this scheme. Credit is being paid where it is due, and I thank them for their cooperation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! A quorum not being present, I will resume the chair at 6.50 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl) took the chair at 6.50 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Ruddock:
That the bill be now read a second time.
upon which Mr Martin Ferguson moved by way of amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House expresses grave concern about:

(1) the lack of parliamentary scrutiny of, and public accountability for, the use of the Minister's power to require the Board of the Agency to implement the "general policies" of the Government in relation to the Agency, the Board or the employees of the Agency:
(2) the Board's unfettered power to set the terms and conditions of the Chief Executive Officer; and
(3) the erosion of public service terms and conditions through the Agency's ability to employ staff under terms and conditions different to those specified in the Public Service Act".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding, Clyde, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —From the outset, I should say that I have no objection in principle to the concept of a one‐stop shop. I am not opposed to the combining of the resources of the current social services offices and the resources of CES offices. But resources are not just the physical offices that we are talking about. They are the human resources, the body of experience, the body of knowledge, the body of caring that has been built up within these Public Service agencies over the years in dealing with what is Australia's major social problem. I refer, of course, to the unacceptably high levels of unemployment in this country which stand at 9.3 per cent nationally and 9.3 per cent in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: It does not matter what government has been in power, in my electorate, particularly in the area of St Kilda which attracts many younger people who have left home and have often come from dysfunctional backgrounds, the figure is always higher in that portion of my electorate than it is nationally. What is wrong with the minister's second reading speech, and with the bill itself, is not what it purports to say, but what it does not purport to say, because the minister's speech is long on rhetoric but very short on detail.

Is it that members supporting the government and this legislation who talk about the need to provide service to their constituents are ignorant of the fact that it is the intention of the government to dismember the CES as we know it? Are they ignorant of the intention to fire, without discrimination and across the board, people with long experience in dealing face‐to‐face with the range of human and social problems of the young unemployed, and the old unemployed, in order to refer—as a result of their ideological position—this very important social question to private employment agencies?

I am not opposed to private employment agencies per se. They are what the large companies use in the headhunting business, and many of them are very successful in that. But when it comes to dealing with many people, particularly young people, who have been unemployed for two years and who have got tired of applying for jobs and writing letters, day after day, I do not believe that any member of this House can have confidence in saying, `That is something that is going to be really looked after by someone who is experienced in finding employment or headhunting people with professional qualifications to service the large corporate sector.'

There is another aspect of this legislation which worries me greatly. I am a firm believer in this parliamentary institution and I am a firm believer in the Westminster system, with all its demerits. I have always believed that it is the best system which currently operates throughout the democratic world. An intrinsic part of that system is that the minister when he takes his oath of office is there to exercise responsibility for the implementation of government policy and he is examinable by any member of the parliament on aspects of his policy in the functioning of his department. We are dealing now with a massive problem of unemployment, one of the biggest social problems in Australia which has all kinds of ramifications. And what are we going to do? We are going to off‐load years of experience, but more importantly we are going to off‐load the role and responsibility of the minister. Here is a concept of ministerial responsibility that I have never met before. We are going to create a board. Nothing wrong with that, except that—listen to this—in designing the framework for the agency the government has taken into account the need for ministerial involvement. Involvement? I always understood that the central concept of our parliamentary experience was not involvement—it was the minister taking responsibility for the implementation of government policy. It was being prepared to accept the responsibility and, if necessary, facing resignation if he failed to implement that policy. We have seen raging in our parliament now for almost a fortnight the problems of a minister who has no confidence in a board, and who is trying to adopt the political position, but they are not prepared to go. But now what we are saying in respect of this very important issue of unemployment is, `Oh well, we have got a totally new concept. We are going to appoint a board'—two from the private sector, two presumably the choice of the minister. But are they subject to the day-to-day control of the minister? Does the minister accept accountability as he is bound to by his oath of office to the parliament?

No. This is an ideologically driven government that deep in its heart believes that anything that is performed by the public sector can be performed more adequately by the private sector. They are entitled to that belief, but it is not supportable in many areas of government. We see failures besetting Great Britain; we see the failures now operating in New Zealand, where there is now in existence a permanent underclass. The way you produce an underclass is to see that there are not useful and meaningful and productive jobs for our citizens. It is not an easy problem but it is one which the government must face up to. But what do they say? `We have got a minister but don't ask him to have a hands-on approach. Don't ask him to line up his public servants and say "I am not happy with the way this particular problem is operating in a particular electorate; I have been besieged by members of my own party and members of the opposition who say it is not working on the ground, what is your answer?"'.

The answer from this minister is to say, `I've got a board. I'm a bit involved. I rang up the chairman the other day. The chairman was not too polite. He said, "Yes, Minister" and "No, Minister", but it is really their responsibility. Do not let the honourable member who is going to follow me in this debate come into my office and ask me, "Now look, Minister, what does this one‐stop shop mean in my electorate?"'

I have a social service structure and several unemployment agencies in my electorate. There is a problem with public transport. If you are unemployed in St Kilda—and mine is a comparatively tight electorate—are you going to put your one‐stop shop in St Kilda or in South Melbourne or in Caulfield, or are you going to have a series of one‐stop shops? Mine is a metropolitan electorate. Where do you put your one‐stop shop in Kalgoorlie or in a rural electorate? Are we going to have a series of them? There is nothing wrong with that, but that is not explained in this bill.

Basically, what you are creating is the very thing which the Minister for Transport has been arguing about for two years. What you are creating is a board with a couple of high‐fliers, the chairman of which is getting a salary which, I believe, exceeds that of the Prime Minister—but he is only the Prime Minister; he only has to come in here and answer questions. That salary is higher than that of any ministers, but they are only parliamentarians and, after all, if you are creating a structure where you do not really have to answer to the parliament, the workload is less onerous.

Under this legislation, the minister can write them a letter. He actually will sit down and write to them and say, `These are the things I want you to do.' Contemplate a situation where they have been meeting. Two of the members are part time—we would not want them to spend too much time dealing with the problems of the unemployed! They will formulate policy. They may choose to tell the minister about it.

Basically, the board is going to be the Trojan Horse which accepts the role and responsibility when unemployment grows, even if the minister is unsatisfactory. We are going to have a replay of some of the problems of a minister who puts himself at arms length from the structure. There will be a further problem for every member of parliament when the minister is operating at arms length.

I have had occasion to contact departmental officers over a period of time to deal with the problems of their structures within my electorate, dealing with complaints about service and the range of problems that go with running these sorts of social welfare structures. Once able to deal directly, because they are public servants, with the people who work in those structures, if they are confronted with the problem of a lack of resources, they will refer you into the department. On every occasion I have been treated with courtesy, concern and always, within the ambit of the huge range of problems they confront, with a resolve to try and deal with the problems that I, as the local member, have raised.

Do we seriously believe in this glib document whose real agenda is to wreak havoc within the Commonwealth Employment Service, to downsize it—that is the fashionable term for giving people the sack—because we have got a board? The members of this board will have to be pretty talented, because they are going to be given the problems. The minister is going to write them a letter, and as a result of getting that letter they are going to solve these problems. Who is kidding who?

BREAK.PARA: The problem with the second reading speech and with the bill itself is that it is not honest: it has not dealt with this parliament honestly and frankly. I would prefer it if the minister and the Prime Minister came in and said, as they often do, `We won the election and our agenda is essentially to destroy the CES. Because of our ideological fixation, we honestly believe that all these private employment agencies could do it just so much better. And your role as the local member? Oh well, you can write me a letter.' I suppose the minister can write another letter. He might even pick up the phone, if the highly paid chief executive officer chooses to speak to him—after all, she gets more money than he does!

The bill ought to be condemned because it does not deal honestly with the problems of those who rely on social services to live. It does not deal with integrity with the problems that face the young unemployed. It is a glib document, because it is about the destruction of existing services, but not on the basis of coming into the parliament and saying that they are totally inefficient and they do not do the job that they were set up to do. It is about all the publicity gimmicks in the world—a one‐stop shop. As I have said, we do not have a problem with the merger: what we do have a problem with is the hidden agenda.

Does the minister say there will not be a downsizing in the CES? Does he say that those essential structures and that experience are going to be maintained? Does he say how many one‐stop shops he is going to need in rural electorates and how many one‐stop shops he is going to need in inner urban electorates? Not a bit of it. Does he deny that, as a result of his ideological commitment and the ideological commitment of this government to their belief—and I think that in many cases it is a genuine belief—and despite all the evidence that is now accumulating throughout the world where other governments have tried to use this system, we have now got a permanent underclass, a group of people who live not within the system but under it. This leads to dysfunctional families and it leads not to solving our social problems but to increasing them.

I now return to the point I was concerned to make as a member of this parliament. I listened with interest to all the new members on the government side say how proud they were to be in this institution and how proud they were to represent their constituents. There was a flush of pride as we learnt of their family history. I can understand all that: I was once a new member of parliament and I can feel their enthusiasm.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a long time ago!

—It was a long time ago. But let me say, as one who values this institution and puts a high priority on its role, that I do not believe that in these essential public policy areas there is any substitute for a minister who is prepared to take responsibility, politically and socially, and take responsibility to this parliament when they are asked about unemployment figures, when they are asked by a member on notice or one who calls around to his or her office and says, `These problems are there. Will you please as minister move on these problems?'. That is the way the system was designed. It was just as well, when this country was fighting for its life, when Great Britain, the founder of these concepts, was fighting for its life, that people did not say, `Gee, we will go out and privatise the army and the navy.'

BREAK.PARA: The concept of the role of parliamentary democracy is a concept that cannot be played with lightly. In my view, the role of the minister is to accept the responsibility for the implementation of policy and create the structures within the structures of government which make the government of the day, whatever its political complexion, answerable to the parliament and its individual members. What we are seeing here is that first of all you create a board, then you dismember the existing Public Service structure, then you privatise—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding) and other previous speakers on this Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill, such as the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) and the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), have eloquently outlined many of its shortcomings and I do not wish to canvass much of the territory that they have already covered. But I do want to say a few things about one aspect of this legislation, which is the way in which it is part of the gutting of the Commonwealth Employment Service, the CES, that publicly funded employment service which has served this nation well for the past 50 years, and the way in which this legislation is part of the Howard government's desire to make the unemployed bear the burden of its drive for cost cutting.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition made no mention of plans to abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service in the 1996 election campaign. Indeed, in a letter to the Community and Public Sector Union it promised to support the CES as a public employment service. It was, however, for those of us with longer memories, an explicit commitment in the extremist Fightback program, the Liberal and National parties' plan to rebuild and reward Australia, launched back in November 1991, on page 218. That plan was rejected by voters at the 1993 election. It said, `Most of the job placement activities of the CES will be privatised or contracted out.' So what we have here is a bill which is another flagrant example of reintroducing the Fightback agenda without the government having any mandate to do so.

There has been a long‐term campaign against the CES from some right‐wing academics, such as Judith Sloane, ideologically opposed to any public sector involvement in the labour market, and I guess it is likely that Prime Minister Howard was influenced by that kind of comment during his period as shadow industrial relations minister. But reports prepared by the department of employment under the Labor government demonstrated unequivocally, I think, that the CES has been absolutely crucial in cutting the numbers of unemployed, and particularly long‐term unemployed, since the recession.

The fact is that nearly two million Australians use the CES each year for one reason or another and its employees are dedicated people who take on the difficult task of matching up the unemployed, the job seekers—not just the better off ones, the better qualified ones—with available vacancies. I think something ought to be said in defence of their contribution and their role. As a member of the federal parliament, and indeed previously as a member of the Victorian state parliament, I have often had occasion to make contact with officers of the Coburg CES, Glenroy CES, Brunswick CES and so on. In each case I found their commitment and dedication to their task to be first class and of immense benefit to people without jobs in my electorate.

But what we will have as a result of this bill is the CES starting to wither on the vine from April as the new Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency commences operations and picks up responsibility for the referral of job seekers, although the CES is apparently not to be formally closed or rebadged as the Public Employment Placement Enterprise until about September. What we have, in effect, is the disappearance of that 50-year‐old comprehensive public employment service—something that taxpayers, in my view, have a right to expect that they and their kids can get assistance from when it is needed.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to lament—as well as lamenting the passing of that comprehensive public employment service—the fact that the PEPE has been excluded from this legislation and, indeed, from other legislation coming before the parliament so that it is not going to be scrutinised by the parliament in contradiction to earlier assurances that we had from the government.

The Public Employment Placement Enterprise will not operate to fill in the gaps in service to the unemployed from commercial and other providers. Instead, as Senator Vanstone informed us on 10 December last year, the Public Employment Placement Enterprise will be incorporated as a company under the Corporations Law and a company structure will ensure it has a `commercial focus' as soon as possible. In my book that means that the Public Employment Placement Enterprise will not be able to effectively look after the unemployed who the new private, profit‐driven employment placement agencies and enterprises do not cater for.

The government has correctly pointed out that Labor first introduced competition from private providers to the traditional dominance of the CES and that this, and particularly in cases of one‐on‐one case management, has worked quite well. But what the new legislation fails to recognise is that the CES needs to continue to play a central role in the provision of employment service to ensure that all those who need case management receive it.

Working Nation involved the strengthening of the CES as well as the introduction of competition and it is that balanced combination of public, community and private sector which has got the results in terms of cutting the numbers of long‐term unemployed to a five‐year low. Under this arrangement, under this bill, we will not have a public employment service provider having the resources to adequately compete. Therefore, you will not get true competition and freedom of choice for all.

The public sector employment enterprise will not be able to compete with Drake and the other private employment agencies, and many of the smaller and more community‐based providers will also find it difficult to get through the tender process and survive in the medium term as employment placement enterprises in comparison with larger commercial enterprises such as Drake.

There are, indeed, a number of unanswered questions about the role of the private employment agencies in bringing about these changes and the money that they are going to make out of unemployment under the new arrangements. I would suggest to the parliament that there is a strong potential for fraud under the proposed arrangements. One of the companies which has been involved here is Drake International. They made a donation to the Liberal Party, and no other party, back in the 1993 election campaign.

Although the government has formally advertised that it will not conduct a nationwide tender process until late March, we already see brand new Drake Job Seek Offices appearing in some areas, presumably in the expectation that they are going to get funding. The government also announced in January that finders' fees would start to be paid to private job placement agencies from February. We can also go back to the report in the Australian from John Short in August last year that it was Prime Minister Howard who personally urged Senator Vanstone at a Cabinet meeting on 9 April last year to undertake the privatisation of the CES.

Another private employment agency which is active in preparation for the new regime is Bensons Hospitality. There have been pretty strong reports that Bensons has been going around headhunting case managers with access to confidential data from the department on how local labour markets operate and the success rates of various case managers and the like.

I am concerned that thousands of public sector jobs will be lost as a result of this legislation and the related legislation. I am also concerned that it will be very difficult for unemployed people to have adequate redress against comparatively powerful profit driven, employment driven placement enterprises under the new arrangements. What we have got here is a bill which is going to abolish the Commonwealth Employment Service and fundamentally change the arrangements for the delivery of employment assistance in Australia, essentially privatising most of this assistance and denying assistance previously available to many.

There are many things to be concerned about. It is the case that the government announced some changes to its original proposals back on 10 December, an indication I think that they recognise that they got it seriously wrong in the first place, and they altered the capacity to benefit test. They talked about having a community support program for the many disadvantaged job seekers who will be excluded from mainstream government employment assistance. But the point is those job seekers are still going to be excluded from this assistance, which until now they have had as a basic right. Despite the changes on 10 December, I am most concerned at how this will operate in practice.

We have a situation where the transferring of staff from the CES will start happening in April and go on apparently through May until the end of the year. The CES will lose its functions in the meantime and I am concerned that if the staff are transferred from the CES to the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency you will have a CES which is unable to provide a universal service in the meantime. It will only provide a service to people who are on unemployment benefits and that will have a number of other adverse effects as well. In the area of staff conditions I understand that while staff being transferred to the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency will stay under public service conditions, the chief executive officer is going to be given the power of hire and fire to take on new staff under the Australian workplace agreements. It is my view that the introduction of these kinds of contracts will weaken staff conditions throughout the Commonwealth services delivery agency in due course.

I am also concerned that it will have an adverse effect on service quality and service standards. Presently the people who are looking for work are able to access the touch screen. In most cases they are referred of course to the CES officers who are able to assist them. If, under the new arrangements, they are not a client of the particular employment placement agency which is matched with the job, they are unlikely to get the job, because the employment placement agency gets paid for placing its own clients. It seems to me that the unemployed are likely to miss out under this arrangement, but also that employers will miss out, because they may find that the pool of people being referred to them is diminished through these restrictions, and that they will not get the best possible applicant for the job.

I am also concerned, as I mentioned earlier, about the possibility of fraud in these circumstances. We will have a situation where employers link up with employment placement enterprises, and indeed are encouraged to do so. Their job will be to provide that employer with clients. We already have some abuses where employers take on people simply in order to take advantage of the job subsidy which applies to particular people and then knock them off at the end of that job subsidy. We have a situation where there is a $10,000 payment for employment placement agencies for difficult to place clients. Now $10,000 is a lot of money, and the incentives for fraud involving employers or even employees in particular arrangements are certainly there. I am concerned that there is not proper monitoring of this arrangement and I am concerned that the establishment of the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency is the first step along this path towards the new private sector employment placement enterprises.

I would seek from the government more information and better responses than it has given us so far, concerning how the community support program will work; whether employers will be in fact worse off through getting in some cases a more limited pool of prospective employees to choose from; and what guarantees we have against fraudulent arrangements. For those reasons I support the amendment moved by the member for Batman, which I think would go a long way towards improving this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In September of last year I indicated that I did not question the notion of a one‐stop shop agency or set‐up, but that I did have concerns about the way in which the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency had been announced and about the lack of detail at that stage. Some six months after the budget announcement about the Services Delivery Agency I am still in the same quandary, because I do not think, even with the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Bill before us that sufficient detail has been revealed about the way in which the agency is to be conducted.

SPEECH.PARA: At the time of the budget, a pamphlet was released as part of the budget kit of the Department of Social Security. It was a glossy, colourful pamphlet entitled `A new era in customer service'. I put a question on notice about it and discovered that this type of pamphlet cost about $30,000 to print. It and a like pamphlet were distributed to targeted community organisations to advise them of the creation of the agency, and another one was targeted at departmental customers. The answer to my question on notice said:
This product also aimed to reassure customers that there would be no interruptions to current payments with the transfer to the new agency.

That is all well and good, and it is important that those who are clients of the departments and other bodies that are to be amalgamated into the agencies should have that assurance. However, I have seen no sign of the type of community consultation it was suggested there would be about the agency.

I am even told that we are still at the stage where various marketing entities for the agency are being market tested to see how people react to them. I have a real problem with the way in which we are going about setting up this agency. I also said in September that one of my grave concerns about the notion of the SDA, the Services Delivery Agency, is that it is the first step towards privatisation/outsourcing of something that has always been part of government services. That is one of the real concerns we need to be aware of. I am also concerned that there appear to be no parameters set as to what the agency will do and how it will go about it. For instance, there has been no discussion about where to locate these agencies.

As I said, I have no problem with trying to put together important arms of government service delivery. In fact, back in 1986 when I was first elected I was surprised that in all the suburbs in the electorate of Scullin, we had a CES in one suburb and the DSS down in the next suburb. As a local member I tried to ensure that, wherever it could be achieved, these services were co‐located. I think the co‐location led to a greater degree of cooperation between the different departments and agencies.

What are we to see here? There are no guidelines about how many agencies there will be or on what criteria decisions will be made about the siting of the agencies. This is a real concern, because in many of the things that the government has done over the last 52 weeks, there seems to be a lack of recognising a basis of need as part of the decisions about where those things are put in place.

Other speakers from the opposition have mentioned that one of the services that will have part of its operations involved in the agency will be the Commonwealth Employment Service. For over 50 years the Commonwealth Employment Service has been essential in delivering a public service. I seek leave to resume my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Latham, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 December 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are negative gearing tax deductions available to companies which (a) do not receive a rental income on property for which loan finance has been secured and (b) have been deregistered by the Australian Securities Commission.
(2) Do taxation law penalties apply to companies claiming the negative gearing deductions referred to in part (1).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)(a) Negative gearing deductions arise for all taxpayers, including companies, in situations where the interest on money borrowed to fund a project is greater than the initial returns of that project. Negative gearing deductions often arise in cases where a rental property has been purchased as the interest cost in the initial years of ownership is high.

Generally, negative gearing deductions only apply to income producing property. However, where a rental property is not producing income but is ready to do so, for example suitable tenants may take some time to find, negative gearing deductions will continue to be allowable.

(1)(b) A company that has been deregistered by the Australian Securities Commission will cease to be a legal entity for taxation purposes and will, therefore, not be required to lodge income tax returns.

(2) A taxpayer, including a company taxpayer, claiming negative gearing deductions is treated, for taxation purposes, no differently from any other taxpayer and the full range of taxation law penalties can be applied where circumstances are appropriate.

Taxpayers are sometimes required to substantiate claims for deductions shown in tax returns. Where a company can demonstrate it has a proper entitlement to a claim for negative gearing deductions, no taxation penalties will be imposed.
